{{EngvarB|date=March 2014}} {{update|date=January 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} [[File:MegaUpload FBI-Banner.jpg|thumb|The seized domain name redirected to this joint [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]], [[United States Department of Justice|DoJ]], and [[National Intellectual Property Rights Coordination Center|NIPRCC]] English notice of federal crime charges.]] The '''Megaupload legal case''' concerns a number of related criminal indictments and enforcement actions taken against [[Megaupload]] owner [[Kim Dotcom]] in various jurisdictions. On 19 January 2012 the [[United States Department of Justice]] seized and shut down the file-hosting site Megaupload.com and commenced [[criminal case]]s against its owners and others. On 20 January 2012 [[Customs and Excise Department (Hong Kong)|Hong Kong Customs]] froze more than 300 million Hong Kong dollars (US$39 million) in assets belonging to the company.<ref>{{Cite news |author= Yung, Chester |title= Hong Kong Freezes Megaupload Assets |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204301404577174362457114578?mod=googlenews_wsj |work=The Wall Street Journal |date= 21 January 2012 |accessdate=21 January 2012}}</ref>
==Arrests in New Zealand== Acting upon a US Federal prosecutor's request, the [[New Zealand Police]] arrested Dotcom and three other Megaupload executives in a leased $30 million mansion at [[Coatesville, New Zealand|Coatesville]] near [[Auckland]] on Friday, 20 January 2012 ([[Time in New Zealand|NZDT]], UTC+13).<ref>{{cite web |title=Megaupload founder arrested in NZ, site shut down |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/megaupload-founder-arrested-in-nz-site-shut-down-4694527 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120123051152/http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/megaupload-founder-arrested-in-nz-site-shut-down-4694527 |archive-date = 2012-01-23 |date=20 January 2012 |accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref> This was pursuant to a request from the U.S. [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] that the four be extradited for racketeering and money laundering.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/digital-life/digital-life-news/fbi-seeks-extradition-of-internet-pirate-20120120-1qacn.html|title=FBI seeks extradition of internet 'pirate'|last=Johnston|first=Kirsty|date=21 January 2012|work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=21 January 2012}}</ref> The raid was timed for the birthday celebration of Dotcom.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10780321 |title=Dotcom birthday party targeted|date=22 January 2012 |accessdate=22 January 2012 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |first=David |last=Fisher}}</ref> Assets worth $17 million including art works and cars were seized. The four men arrested were [[Kim Dotcom]] (founder; 38 years old, from Germany), Finn Batato ([[Chief marketing officer]] (CMO); 38, from Germany), Mathias Ortmann ([[Chief technology officer]] (CTO) and co-founder; 40, from Germany) and Bram van der Kolk (29, from the Netherlands).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nz.news.yahoo.com/a/-/top-stories/12676694/search-at-dotcom-mansion-ends/|title=Dotcom in New Zealand|date=22 January 2012|accessdate=22 January 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120722175938/http://nz.news.yahoo.com/a/-/top-stories/12676694/search-at-dotcom-mansion-ends/|archivedate=22 July 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/6293542/Megaupload-attempting-to-get-back-online|title=Website fights back|date=22 January 2012 |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10780142 |title=New Zealand police complete Dotcom search|date=22 January 2012 |accessdate=22 January 2012 |work=The New Zealand Herald |first=Anna |last=Leask}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Megaupload-founder-arrested-in-Auckland-site-shut-down/tabid/412/articleID/240007/Default.aspx |title=Megaupload founder arrested in Auckland, site shut down |publisher=3news.co.nz |date=19 January 2012 |accessdate=19 January 2012}}</ref> The number of police officers involved in this operation was about 80 according to Dotcom<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10783521 | work=The New Zealand Herald | first=David | last=Fisher | title=Details of 'surprise assault' on Dotcom mansion | date=5 February 2012}}</ref> or 20 to 30 according to the New Zealand police.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/04/technology/megaupload-founder-goes-from-arrest-to-cult-hero.html?ref=global-home|work=The New York Times | first=Jonathan | last=Hutchison | title=Megaupload Founder Goes From Arrest to Cult Hero| date=3 July 2012}}</ref>
On 23 January, Dotcom appeared in Auckland's North Shore [[District Court of New Zealand|District Court]] for a bail hearing. The crown argued against bail on the basis that he was a flight risk with a helicopter on his front lawn, while defence lawyers argued that the helicopter could not fly far enough to reach another country. They also said that Dotcom denied any criminal wrongdoing. Judge David McNaughton expressed concern at the discovery of two shotguns at Dotcom's mansion during the police raid,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Megaupload-accused-Kim-Schmitz-in-court-helicopter-part-of-bail-debate/tabid/423/articleID/240281/Default.aspx |title=Megaupload accused Kim Schmitz in court, helicopter part of bail debate |publisher=3news.co.nz |date=23 January 2012 |accessdate=23 January 2012}}</ref> and deferred a decision on whether to grant bail, saying that he needed more time to review the submissions.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203806504577178830739157386?mod=googlenews_wsj |title=Judge Delays Kim Dotcom Bail Decision |work=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=24 January 2012 |accessdate=24 January 2012 |first=Lucy |last=Craymer}}</ref> The request for bail was turned down, with Judge McNaughton saying that "he was denied due to the risk [that] Mr. Dotcom would flee jurisdiction and the possibility that if he reached Germany he wouldn't be extradited to face the charges".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wordswithmeaning.org/2012/01/megaupload-founder-has-been-denied-bail/ |title=Megaupload Founder has been DENIED Bail |publisher=Wordswithmeaning.org |accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref> On 3 February 2012, an appeal to the [[High Court of New Zealand]] upheld the decision to deny bail.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-16869788|title=Megaupload co-founder's bail appeal rejected by court|publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=3 February 2012|accessdate=3 February 2012}}</ref>
On 22 February 2012, North Shore District Court Judge Nevin Dawson overturned the previous rulings and granted bail to Kim Dotcom,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wordswithmeaning.org/2012/02/kim-dotcom-released-from-prison|title=WordswithMeaning! - Kim Dotcom Released From Prison|work=WordswithMeaning!|accessdate=11 May 2015}}</ref> saying that the risk of flight had diminished after his assets had been seized.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-17122866|title=Megaupload founder Kim Dotcom granted bail|publisher=BBC News |date=22 February 2012|accessdate=22 February 2012}}</ref>
On 5 March 2012, a formal request for the [[extradition]] to the United States of Kim Dotcom and three other senior Megaupload staff was filed in a New Zealand court.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-17257308|title=Megaupload founder extradition papers filed by US|publisher=BBC News |date=5 March 2012|accessdate=5 March 2012}}</ref>
On 30 April 2012, the New Zealand High Court ruled that around $750,000 of Kim Dotcom's assets could be returned, including a [[Mercedes-Benz G-Class|Mercedes-Benz G55 AMG]] and [[Toyota Alphard|Toyota Vellfire]] that had been seized during the raid on his home. The assets in 63 bank accounts and around thirty other vehicles remained in custody.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.autoevolution.com/news/megaupload-founder-kim-schmitz-assets-worth-750000-returned-44480.html |title=Megaupload Founder Kim Schmitz: Assets Worth $750,000 Returned |publisher=autoevolution.com |date=30 April 2012 |accessdate=4 May 2012}}</ref> A paperwork error by the New Zealand authorities meant that Kim Dotcom's property had been seized in January 2012 without giving proper notice. The restraining order on his property was granted in April 2012. During April 2012, US district court judge [[Liam O'Grady]] stated "I frankly don't know that we are ever going to have a trial in this matter," as he found out that the company had never been formally served with criminal papers by the US.<ref name="grady">{{cite news|last=Fisher|first=David|title=Dotcom trial may not occur - Judge|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10800409|accessdate=20 August 2012|newspaper=The New Zealand Herald|date=21 April 2012}}</ref>
On 28 June 2012, [[High Court of New Zealand|New Zealand High Court]] judge Justice Helen Winkelmann ruled that the [[search warrant]]s used to raid the home of Kim Dotcom were invalid, saying "The warrants did not adequately describe the offences to which they related. They were general warrants, and as such, are invalid."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-18623043|title=Megaupload raid warrant 'invalid', New Zealand judge says|publisher=BBC News |date=28 June 2012|accessdate=30 June 2012}}</ref>
On 10 July 2012, a decision on whether Kim Dotcom and other Megaupload employees should be extradited to the United States was delayed until March 2013, in order to allow further time for legal arguments to be heard.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-18779866#|title=Megaupload extradition case delayed until March 2013|publisher=BBC News |date=10 July 2012|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref> In December 2012, it was delayed until August 2013.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10855130| title=Dotcom extradition case delayed until August| date=19 December 2012| publisher= New Zealand Herald}}</ref>
In March 2013, Dotcom won a Court of Appeal ruling allowing him to sue the [[Government Communications Security Bureau]] (GCSB),<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Dotcom-wins-right-to-sue-Govt-spies/tabid/423/articleID/289342/Default.aspx|work=[[3 News NZ]] | title= Dotcom wins right to sue Govt spies| date=7 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10869764 |work=NZ Herald |title=Dotcom wins right to sue| date=7 March 2013}}</ref> rejecting the attorney-general's appeal against a ruling in December, 2012.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Crown-wants-GCSB-exluded-from-Dotcom-case/tabid/423/articleID/286755/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ | title= Crown wants GCSB exluded from Dotcom case| date=7 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/128063/judge-describes-dotcom-case-as-a-procedural-mess |work=[[Radio NZ]]|title=Judge describes Dotcom case as a procedural mess| date=14 February 2013}}</ref>
On 19 February 2014, a New Zealand appeals court overruled the 28 June 2012 decision, declaring the search warrants against Kim Dotcom to be valid. Dotcom's extradition hearing was set for July 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tajitsu|first=Naomi|title=NZ court rules Megaupload warrant legal, dealing blow to Dotcom|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/02/19/us-newzealand-megaupload-warrant-idUSBREA1I02F20140219|work=Reuters|publisher=Thompson Reuters|accessdate=13 March 2014|date=18 January 2014}}</ref>
On 8 September 2014, the Court of Appeal ruled that the New Zealand Police is to return seized electronic devices unencrypted back to Dotcom and those involved.<ref name="winforDotcom">{{cite news | url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11320761 | title=A win for Dotcom over seized property | work=The New Zealand Herald | date=8 September 2014 | accessdate=9 September 2014 | author=Bayer, Kurt | pages=1}}</ref>
==Basis of indictment== [[File:MegaUploadIndictment.jpg|thumb|The first page of the indictment, listing the defendants<ref name="indictment" />]] The indictment<ref name="indictment">{{cite web|title=Megaupload Indictment|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/78786408/Mega-Indictment|accessdate=20 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=U.S. Shuts Offshore File-Share 'Locker'|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204616504577171060611948408|accessdate=20 August 2012|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=20 January 2012}}</ref> alleged that Megaupload differed from other online [[File hosting service|file storage businesses]].
Media reports covering the case highlighted a number of points from the indictment used to support claims of illegal activity. The indictment provided a number of instances alleged to show criminal behaviour, as well as indicating design points of Megaupload's [[business model|operating model]] as being evidence of [[intention (criminal law)|criminal intent]]:<ref name="indictment" />
# In practice, the "vast majority" of users do not have any significant long term private storage capability. Continued storage is dependent upon regular downloads of the file occurring. Files not downloaded are rapidly removed in most cases, whereas popular downloaded files are retained. (items 7 – 8) # Because only a small portion of users pay for storage, the business is dependent upon advertising. Adverts are primarily viewed when files are downloaded and the business model is therefore not based upon storage but upon maximising downloads. (items 7 – 8) # Persons indicted have "instructed individual users how to locate links to infringing content on the Mega Sites ... [and] ... have also shared with each other comments from Mega Site users demonstrating that they have used or are attempting to use the Mega Sites to get infringing copies of copyrighted content." (item 13) # Persons indicted, unlike the public, are not reliant upon links to stored files, but can search the internal database directly. It is claimed they have "searched the internal database for their associates and themselves so that they may directly access copyright-infringing content". (item 14) # A comprehensive takedown method is in use to identify [[child pornography]], but not deployed to remove infringing content. (item 24) # Infringing users did not have their accounts terminated, and the defendants "made no significant effort to identify users who were using the Mega Sites or services to infringe copyrights, to prevent the uploading of infringing copies of copyrighted materials, or to identify infringing copies of copyrighted works" (item 55–56) # An incentivising program was adopted encouraging the upload of "popular" files in return for payments to successful uploaders. (item 69e ''et al.'') # Defendants explicitly discussed evasion and infringement issues, including an attempt to copy and upload the entire content of YouTube. (items 69i-l. YouTube: items 69 i,j,l,s)
=== Counter arguments advanced === Schmitz hired the services of Ira Rothken, an attorney who defended several copyright infringement cases. Rothken claims that the raid was unjustly swift and did not give his client the opportunity to defend himself, quoting a similar case involving YouTube as an example of a completely different turnout.<ref name="def">{{cite web | url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-31001_3-57362609-261/megaupload-assembles-worldwide-criminal-defense/ | title=Megaupload assembles worldwide criminal defense | publisher=[[CNET]] | date=20 January 2012 | accessdate=20 January 2012 | author=Sandoval, Greg}}</ref><ref name="washingtonpost.com">{{cite news| first=Cecilia| last=Kang| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/technology/megaupload-lawyer-qanda-on-doj-criminal-case/2012/01/20/gIQA3HJhDQ_story.html| title=Megaupload lawyer Q&A on DOJ criminal case| publisher=[[Washington Post]]| date=20 January 2012}}</ref>
Legal commentators point out that while the indictment may be correct and Megaupload might have acted as a criminal conspiracy as claimed, a number of points in the indictment are based upon selective interpretations and legal concepts (described in one article as "novel theories" of the law<ref name="latimes novel">{{cite web|url=http://opinion.latimes.com/opinionla/2012/01/copyrights-feds-push-novel-theories-in-megaupload-case.html|title=Opinion L.A.|publisher=|accessdate=11 May 2015}}</ref>) and could be challenged in court. An [[L.A. Times]] analysis stated that the author was "struck by how far the indictment goes to find something nefarious";<ref name="latimes novel" /> likewise a [[TechDirt]] analysis concluded that while the [[Kim Dotcom|founder of Megaupload]] had a significant history of "flaunting the law", evidence has potentially been taken out of context or misrepresented and could "come back to haunt other online services who are providing perfectly legitimate services".<ref name="techdirt analysis">{{cite web| url=http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20120120/00373617487/megaupload-details-raise-significant-concerns-about-what-doj-considers-evidence-criminal-behavior.shtml| title=Megaupload Details Raise Significant Concerns About What DOJ Considers Evidence Of Criminal Behavior| first=Mike| last=Masnick| publisher=techdirt| date=20 January 2012}}</ref> Both analyses concur that other evidence could show criminality; the concerns were not irrefutable. The legal concerns included:
:* Indictment cites lack of a site search as evidence supporting criminality, but in other copyright cases having a site search has been described as evidence in support of criminality and in ''[[Legal aspects of file sharing#Legal issues relevant to file sharing|Atari v. RapidShare]]'' <u>not</u> having a site search was agreed by the court as evidence of responsible activity given that some infringing content might exist and be searched for if one existed.<ref name="latimes novel" /> In the case of ''Isohunt'', the ''presence'' of a search feature was interpreted as evidence of inducement.<ref name="techdirt analysis" /> [[TechDirt]] commented that "To use the lack of a feature, that previously was shown to be a problem, as evidence of a conspiracy is crazy. Damned if you do, damned if you don't."<ref name="techdirt analysis" /> :* The "top 100" list excluded copyrighted titles, but the indictment claims this was evidence of concealing, rather than avoiding downloads of, infringing materials.<ref name="latimes novel" /><ref name="techdirt analysis" /> :* The indictment asserts as evidence that no effort was made to identify infringing files or users, in other words by acts of omission. But federal court rulings repeatedly agree that no duty exists to search these out.<ref name="latimes novel" /> In particular, in ''[[MGM Studios, Inc. v. Grokster, Ltd.]]'' the Supreme Court looked at "substantial noninfringing uses"; mere lack of monitoring was not by itself sufficient to show wrongdoing or inducement.<ref name="latimes novel" /> It may not be possible (or reasonable to require) the host to know and identify what activity is legitimate or not, as file sharing may be used by many content creators.<ref name="techdirt analysis" /> :* Deletion after a limited period of non-download is suggested as evidence of a motive. But many legitimate sites such as [[Imgur]] remove unused content after a while to free up server space. If files were routinely deleted after a short period it could equally suggest legitimate use - because it serves users who share legitimately for a short while, and enforces removal afterwards.<ref name="techdirt analysis" /> :* Much of the indictment, in the words of one analysis, "seems to be based on the simple assumption that encouraging more usage means they must be encouraging infringement", in other words there should be evidence of actual wrongdoing, not merely evidence of popular use. Many legitimate files are popular and popularly shared, and an assumption that paid use largely equates to infringing use would need evidence.<ref name="techdirt analysis" /> :* Failure to remove all links following a takedown request is often legitimate. For example the same content may be uploaded by legitimate and illegitimate users. Removing the infringing ''link'' does not affect legitimate uploaders. Removing the infringing ''file'' would wrongfully cause it to be deleted for legitimate users too.<ref name="techdirt analysis" /> Similarly, once child pornography is identified, it is ''always'' illegal for ''all'' users. But other material may be legal for some users and not for others. So the fact one case requires ''file'' removal and the other only requires ''link'' removal may well be correct conduct.<ref name="techdirt analysis" /> :* The indictment includes [[money laundering]] charges. But these include "basic payments" for web hosting, suggesting "lumping in" — adding matters that are in no way illegal to make a case look bad.<ref name="techdirt analysis" /> :* Megaupload had indicated willingness to attend court in the U.S. already, and answer civil cases.<ref name="techdirt analysis" />
===Safe harbor provisions=== The US [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] provides [[Safe harbor (law)|safe harbor]] for sites that promptly take down infringing content. Safe harbor does not exist if the site has [[actual knowledge]] and does nothing about it.<ref>{{cite web|last=Anderson |first=Nate |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2012/01/why-the-feds-smashed-megaupload.ars |title=Why the feds smashed Megaupload |publisher=Arstechnica.com |date=10 November 2011 |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref>
In Megaupload's case, the indictment alleges DMCA provisions were used for the appearance of legitimacy – the actual material was not removed, only some links to it were, takedowns agreement was approved based on business growth rather than infringement, and the parties themselves openly discussed their infringing activities. The indictment claims that Megaupload executives:
<blockquote>... are willfully infringing copyrights themselves on these systems; have actual knowledge that the materials on their systems are infringing (or alternatively know facts or circumstances that would make infringing material apparent); receive a financial benefit directly attributable to copyright-infringing activity where the provider can control that activity; and have not removed, or disabled access to, known copyright infringing material from servers they control.<ref>Paragraph 20, page 9 of the indictment</ref></blockquote>
Prosecutors claimed in the indictment that Megaupload was not DMCA compliant, and cited the example of an alleged infringer on the site known as "VV." Over six years, VV had allegedly uploaded nearly 17,000 files to Megavideo.com, resulting in more than 334 million views. According to prosecutors, although numerous takedown e-mails had been sent, none of the files had been deleted.<ref name="DMCA">{{cite news | url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/02/17/justice/megaupload-com-indictment/| title=Feds broaden piracy case against Megaupload.com|publisher=CNN | date=18 February 2012 | accessdate=22 February 2012}}</ref>
In a television interview with [[3 News]], Kim Dotcom denied being a "piracy king", and claimed that Megaupload had applied the provisions of the DMCA and went beyond it, by giving copyright holders direct rights to delete links. He also claimed that the indictment relied on a malicious interpretation of technical issues to construe its claim of criminal intent, and that there was significant legal use of Megaupload.<ref name="3news">{{cite web| url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Kim-Dotcoms-first-TV-interview-Im-no-piracy-king/tabid/817/articleID/244830/Default.aspx| title=Kim Dotcom's first TV interview: 'I'm no piracy king'| publisher=[[3 News]]| date=1 March 2012| accessdate=28 April 2012| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120729131119/http://www.3news.co.nz/Kim-Dotcoms-first-TV-interview-Im-no-piracy-king/tabid/817/articleID/244830/Default.aspx| archivedate=29 July 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Criminal defense action== Kim Dotcom denied the charges filed against him, and retained the services of [[Ira P. Rothken]], an attorney who has defended several copyright infringement cases. Ira Rothken stated that there is no criminal liability for secondary copyright infringement under US law, quoting a similar case involving YouTube as an example of similar accusations which were dealt with as a civil case.<ref name="def"/><ref name="washingtonpost.com"/>
Dotcom initially hired Washington, D.C. attorney [[Robert S. Bennett|Robert Bennett]], who had confirmed that he was going to represent Megaupload in the piracy case.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/technology/dc-attorney-robert-bennett-to-represent-megaupload-in-piracy-case-promises-vigorous-defense/2012/01/20/gIQAPCzGEQ_story.html |title=DC attorney Robert Bennett to represent Megaupload in piracy case, promises vigorous defense |work=Washington Post |date= 20 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.boston.com/business/technology/articles/2012/01/20/renowned_attorney_bennett_to_represent_megaupload_1327113598/ |title=Renowned attorney Bennett to represent Megaupload |work=Associated Press |date= 20 January 2012}}</ref> On 22 January 2012, Bennett withdrew from the case due to a conflict of interest with another client.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2012/01/22/megauploads-high-profile-defense-lawyer-robert-bennett-withdraws-from-piracy-case/ |title=megauploads high-profile defense lawyer robert bennett withdraws from piracy case |work=National Post |location=Canada |accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Ingram |first=David |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/22/us-usa-megaupload-bennett-idUSTRE80L0UV20120122 |title=Reuters.com |agency=Reuters |date= 22 January 2012|accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref> As of 23 January, barrister Paul Davison QC was quoted as representing Megaupload's founder, Kim Dotcom, in New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web |title=Megaupload boss says innocent, rival stops file-sharing |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2012/01/23/internet-piracy-megaupload-idUKL4E8CN3X620120123 |work=Reuters |date=23 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.nzbar.org.nz/Person?Action=Profile&Person_id=425| title=Paul Davison QC| publisher= NZ Barr Association| accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref> At the end of April 2012, a controversy emerged over legal representation. The law firm [[Quinn Emanuel Urquhart & Sullivan|Quinn Emanuel]], retained by Megaupload to argue for the retention of Megaupload's data, claimed in a motion filed to the court that there was a concerted effort by the [[United States Department of Justice]] to deny Megaupload fair legal representation. In the brief, Quinn Emanuel alleged that several law firms had dropped out of the case after the DoJ wrote to them over potential conflicts of interest, arguing that they wanted to call clients of the firms as witnesses. Given the size of the Megaupload, Quinn Emanuel claimed that this "conflict of interest" argument could be applied to any law firm with experience in intellectual property rights, denying Megaupload experienced representation in a case where both law and technical issues are involved. Quinn Emanuel received such a letter but rejected the DoJ's arguments.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2012/04/government-trying-to-deny-megaupload-legal-representation.ars?clicked=related_right|title=Government trying to deny Megaupload fair legal representation|publisher=[[Ars Technica]] |date=16 April 2012 |accessdate=28 April 2012}}</ref>
[[Techdirt]] argued that while the [[Kim Dotcom|founder of Megaupload]] had a significant history of "flouting the law", evidence had potentially been taken out of context or misrepresented and could "come back to haunt other online services who are providing perfectly legitimate services".<ref name="techdirt analysis"/> [[Eric Goldman]], a professor of law at [[Santa Clara University]], described the Megaupload case as "a depressing display of abuse of government authority". He pointed out that criminal copyright infringement requires that willful infringement has taken place, and that taking Megaupload offline had produced the "deeply unconstitutional effect" of denying legitimate users of the site access to their data.<ref name="goldman">{{cite web|last=Goldman|first=Eric|title=Comments on the Megaupload Prosecution (a Long-Delayed Linkwrap)|url=http://blog.ericgoldman.org/archives/2012/04/megaupload.htm|work=Technology & Marketing Blog|accessdate=20 August 2012}}</ref> Other legal commentators have disagreed with Goldman's assessment of the copyright charges, concluding that the allegations in the indictment, if proven, would support a guilty finding on charges of aiding and abetting copyright infringement.<ref name="Benton Martin">{{citation|last=Benton Martin |first=Jeremiah Newhall |title=Criminal Copyright Enforcement against Filesharing Services |date=6 March 2013 |ssrn=2229376 }}</ref> Professor James Grimmelmann, for example, commented, "If proven at trial, there's easily enough in the indictment to prove criminal copyright infringement many times over."<ref>{{cite web|last=Anderson |first=Nate |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2012/01/why-the-feds-smashed-megaupload.ars |title=Why the feds smashed Megaupload |publisher=Arstechnica.com |date=10 November 2011 |accessdate=22 January 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120713194540/http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2012/01/why-the-feds-smashed-megaupload/ |archivedate=13 July 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
The defense has drawn on procedural errors by the prosecution to challenge the case. In a judgement in the end of May, NZ Judge David Harvey granted the defendants the right to the disclosure of evidence against them held by the FBI in preparation for the extradition trial.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/05/30/digital-notes-judge-presses-u-s-in-megaupload-case/ | work=The New York Times | first=Ben | last=Sisario | title=Digital Notes: Judge Presses U.S. in Megaupload Case | date=30 May 2012}}</ref> In his 81-page decision, he came to the assessment that the DoJ is attempting to use concepts of civil law, in particular secondary copyright infringement, in a criminal case, which creates legal issues. He also confirmed that the charges in the indictment relating to money laundering, racketeering and wire fraud are not separate criminal acts but dependent on the claim of criminal secondary copyright infringement.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/95215045/Torrent-Freak-Mega-Extra|title=Torrent Freak Mega Extra|publisher=|accessdate=11 May 2015}}</ref> In a separate development in the United States, the defense has challenged the case against Megaupload as a whole, claiming that the US has no jurisdiction over a foreign company and that the seizure of Megaupload's assets was unlawful.<ref name="nojurisdiction">{{Cite Pacer | plaintiff = USA | defendant = Dotcom | date = May 30, 2012 | case-division = 1 | case-year = 2012a | case-type = cr | case-sequence = 00003 | case-state = va | case-district = ed | recap-number = 275313 | pacer-number = 275312 | access-date = Jul 23, 2017 | use-pacer = yes | use-recap = yes | case-title = USA v. Dotcom et. al. | title = Motion Of Specially-Appearing Defendant Megaupload Limited To Dismiss Indictment | doc-number = 96 | att-number = 1 }}</ref> A second brief points out numerous legal errors in the indictment, declaring it "an experiment in stretching U.S. criminal law well past the breaking point."<ref name="experiment">{{Cite Pacer | plaintiff = USA | defendant = Dotcom | date = May 30, 2012 | case-division = 1 | case-year = 2012b | case-type = cr | case-sequence = 00003 | case-state = va | case-district = ed | recap-number = 275313 | pacer-number = 275312 | access-date = Jul 23, 2017 | use-pacer = no | use-recap = yes | case-title = USA v. Dotcom et. al. | title = Motion To Challenge The Scope Of Pretrial Restraint Of Assets | doc-number = 96 | att-number = 2 }} p. 2</ref>
==Data retention== Following the seizure of Megaupload, concerns were raised as to what would happen to the files that had been uploaded by its users.<ref name=Chloe1>{{cite news|last=Albanesius|first=Chloe|title=Megaupload Shutdown Targets Pirates ... And Legitimate Files|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2399134,00.asp|accessdate=31 January 2012|newspaper=PC Magazine|date=20 January 2012}}</ref> On 20 January 2012, the Justice Department stated that "It is important to note that Mega clearly warned users to keep copies of any files they uploaded" adding that "Megaupload.com expressly informed users through its Frequently Asked Questions ('FAQs') and its Terms of Service that users have no proprietary interest in any of the files on Megaupload's servers, they assume the full risk of complete loss or unavailability of their data, and that Megaupload can terminate site operations without prior notice."<ref name=Chloe2>{{cite news|last=Albanesius|first=Chloe|title=Recovering Legitimate Megaupload Files? Good Luck With That|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2399162,00.asp|accessdate=31 January 2012|date=20 January 2012|work=PC Magazine}}</ref> On 27 January 2012, U.S. Attorney Neil H. MacBride wrote:
<blockquote>The Mega Servers are not in the actual or constructive custody or control of the United States, but remain at the premises controlled by, and currently under the control of, Carpathia and Cogent. Should the defendants wish to obtain independent access to the Mega Servers, or coordinate third-party access to data housed on Mega Servers, the issue must be resolved directly with Cogent or Carpathia.<ref name=Gallagher1>{{cite news|last=Gallagher|first=Sean|title=Feds: Megaupload user files may be deleted starting Thursday|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2012/01/feds-give-ok-to-deleting-megaupload-user-files-starting-thursday.ars|accessdate=31 January 2012|newspaper=Arstechnica|date=30 January 2012}}</ref><ref name=Chloe3>{{cite news|last=Albanesius|first=Chloe|title=Megaupload Files: Deleted By Thursday?|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2399525,00.asp|accessdate=31 January 2012|newspaper=PC Magazine|date=30 January 2012}}</ref></blockquote>
In response, on 30 January 2012, Carpathia Hosting denied having access to MegaUpload files and issued a press release stating
<blockquote>Carpathia Hosting does not have, and has never had, access to the content on MegaUpload servers and has no mechanism for returning any content residing on such servers to MegaUpload's customers. The reference to the 2 February 2012 date in the Department of Justice letter for the deletion of content is not based on any information provided by Carpathia to the U.S. Government. We would recommend that anyone who believes that they have content on MegaUpload servers contact MegaUpload. Please do not contact Carpathia Hosting.<ref name=ch1>{{cite news|title=Carpathia Hosting's Statement on Recent News Reports |url=http://www.carpathia.com/carpathia-hostings-statement-on-recent-news-reports |accessdate=31 January 2012 |newspaper=Carpathia Hosting |date=30 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130235807/http://www.carpathia.com/carpathia-hostings-statement-on-recent-news-reports |archivedate=30 January 2012 }}</ref><ref name=Hayley1>{{cite news|last=Tsukayama|first=Hayley|title=Carpathia: Don't call us for Megaupload data|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/technology/carpathia-dont-call-us-for-megaupload-data/2012/01/30/gIQADsMKdQ_story.html|accessdate=31 January 2012|newspaper=Washington Post|date=30 January 2012}}</ref> </blockquote>
The [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] has started a campaign to allow legitimate users of Megaupload in the US access to their data and wants the data preserved for that reason. It has chosen to represent one such legitimate user in court and thus has sided with Megaupload and Carpathia in asking the court to retain the data.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.eff.org/press/releases/megaupload-user-asks-court-return-his-video-files| title=Megaupload User Asks Court to Return His Video Files| date=30 March 2012| publisher=[[Electronic Frontier Foundation|EFF]]}}</ref>
On 26 April 2012, Megaupload data negotiations began. Carpathia reported that maintaining the data costs over 9,000 USD a day, and wanted to seek a formal resolution on whether to delete the data or release it to interested parties. United States district court Judge Liam O'Grady ordered all parties to return to the negotiating table. The U.S. Department of Justice noted that 35 million USD had been paid by Megaupload to Carpathia, and alleged that Carpathia had knowingly profited from copyright infringement.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/us-megauploads-hosting-company-might-be-sued-next-120415/|title=US: Megaupload's Hosting Company Might be Sued Next - TorrentFreak|work=TorrentFreak|accessdate=11 May 2015}}</ref>
==Retaliatory attacks by Anonymous== Following the shutdown of the Megaupload website, the website of the [[United States Department of Justice]] and a number of other websites were taken offline following concerted [[denial of service]] attacks attributed to [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Anonymous in revenge attack for MegaUpload shutdown|url=http://blogs.ft.com/fttechhub/2012/01/anonymous-megaupload-ddos/#axzz1k55k0F00|newspaper=Financial Times}}</ref><ref name="BBC">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-11371315|title=Activists target recording industry websites|date=20 September 2012|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref><ref name="Telegraph">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/internet/8013548/Music-and-film-industry-websites-targeted-in-cyber-attacks.html|title=Music and film industry websites targeted in cyber attacks|last=Beaumont|first=Claudine|date=20 September 2012|work=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=September 30, 2012}}</ref>
[[Gizmodo]] concurred that it was "almost certainly the result of a quickly assembled [[DDoS]] [Distributed Denial of Service] attack—and easily the widest in scope and ferocity we've seen in some time", commenting that "if you had any doubts Anonymous is still a hacker wrecking ball, doubt no more".<ref name="Gizmodo" /> Links posted in chatrooms and on [[Twitter]], when clicked on by unsuspecting Internet users, ran a web version of the application known as the [[Low Orbit Ion Cannon]]. On 19 January 2012, Anonymous released a statement on Pastebin.com accepting responsibility of the mass attacks on websites including those of RIAA, MPAA, BMI, FBI, and others.<ref>{{cite web|title=Anonymous post on Pastebin|url=http://pastebin.com/WEydcBVV}}</ref> According to the Russian state-run<ref>Burton, C., Drake, A. Hitting the Headlines In Europe, A Country-By-Country Guide to Effective Media Relations. Kogan Page Ltd. 2004. p. 163.</ref><ref>''Stanford Journal of International Law'', Volume 38, 2002. p. 26.</ref> [[RT (TV network)|RT network]], Anonymous described the attacks as "the single largest Internet attack in its history".<ref name="Gizmodo">{{cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/5877679/anonymous-kills-department-of-justice-site-in-megaupload-revenge-strike|title=Anonymous Goes on Megaupload Revenge Spree: DoJ, RIAA, MPAA, and Universal Music All Offline|last=Biddle|first=Sam|date=19 January 2012|publisher=[[Gizmodo]]|accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref><ref name="Huff">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/01/19/anonymous-megaupload_n_1217418.html|title=Anonymous Responds To Megaupload Takedown; Claims Credit For DOJ, RIAA, MPAA, Universal Music Outages (UPDATE)|last=Smith|first=Gerry|date=19 January 2012|publisher=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref>
==Other reactions== Former French president [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] said he was satisfied with the shutdown of the website. He found the site's operators were reaping "criminal profits from the illegal distribution of copyrighted works". "The time has come for increased judicial and police co-operation between states" in the fight against online piracy, he said in a statement.<ref>{{cite news|title=FBI unplugs top piracy site|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/fbi-unplugs-top-piracy-site/story-e6frg6so-1226249800286|work=The Australian|accessdate=20 January 2012|date=20 January 2012}}</ref>
Web organisations have raised concerns about possible effects of the Megaupload case on the future of [[file sharing]], [[cloud storage]], and [[Internet commerce]].<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/21/technology/antipiracy-case-sends-shivers-through-some-legitimate-storage-sites.html Antipiracy Case Sends Shivers Through Some Legitimate Storage Sites ([[New York Times]], 20 January 2012)]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/technology/megaupload-shutdown-raises-new-internet-sharing-fears/2012/01/20/gIQATHRtEQ_story.html|title=Megaupload shutdown raises new Internet-sharing fears|work=Washington Post|accessdate=11 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/story/2012-01-20/megaupload-arrests-FBI/52697186/1|title=Takedown of Megaupload leads to fears Internet commerce will suffer – USATODAY.com|work=USATODAY.COM|accessdate=11 May 2015}}</ref> Various commentators including [[John C. Dvorak]], [[Glenn Greenwald]], and [[Julian Sanchez (writer)|Julian Sanchez]] have written on the topic as well, particularly as it relates US government powers to take down a web site without a trial, even without new laws like [[Stop Online Piracy Act|SOPA]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Dvorak |first=John C. |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2399174,00.asp |title=U.S. Government Kills Megaupload |publisher=PCMag.com|accessdate=22 January 2012 |date=20 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Greenwald |first=Glenn |url=http://www.salon.com/2012/01/21/two_lessons_from_the_megaupload_seizure/singleton/ |title=Two lessons from the Megaupload seizure |publisher=Salon.com |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cato-at-liberty.org/fbi-reminds-us-government-already-has-megapower-to-take-down-websites/ |title=FBI Reminds Us Government Already Has MegaPower to Take Down Websites|publisher=Cato-at-liberty.org |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2012/01/20/145529027/five-questions-answers-about-the-megaupload-case |title=5 Questions, Answers About The Megaupload Case |publisher=Npr.org |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> In fact, the [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Dept of Justice]] was able to rely on [[PRO-IP Act|PRO-IP]], a law passed back in 2008, in order to shut down Megaupload.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2012/0121/If-feds-can-bust-Megaupload-why-bother-with-anti-piracy-bills|title=If feds can bust Megaupload, why bother with anti-piracy bills?|author=The Christian Science Monitor|work=The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=11 May 2015}}</ref>
People who used Megaupload for personal and business storage, such as large audio and video files for family and work, have also voiced their complaints about the fact that they no longer had access to their files on the service.<ref name="ars users">{{cite web|last=Brodkin |first=Jon |url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/news/2012/01/megaupload-wasnt-just-for-pirates-angry-users-out-of-luck-for-now.ars |title=Megaupload wasn't just for pirates: angry users out of luck for now |publisher=Arstechnica.com |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Albanesius |first=Chloe |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2399162,00.asp |title=Recovering Legitimate Megaupload Files? Good Luck With That (PC Magazine) |publisher=Pcmag.com |date=1 January 1970 |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> Examples cited in the media included staff at public interest group ''[[Public Knowledge]]'' who used it for large files, and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] cellphone software writers who described it as "one of the best ways to distribute [software] ... There are a number of similar sites for this use, but Megaupload was always the fastest".<ref name="ars users" />
In response to the shutdown, a number of other file hosting websites changed the functionality of their services. FileSonic.com, one of the top ten [[file hosting service]]s, withdrew the ability to share links to files. The site's main page added a banner stating "All sharing functionality on FileSonic is now disabled. Our service can only be used to upload and retrieve files that you have uploaded personally."<ref>{{cite web|title=FileSonic disables file sharing in wake of MegaUpload arrests|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1023_3-57363594-93/filesonic-disables-file-sharing-in-wake-of-megaupload-arrests/|work=[[CNET]]|accessdate=23 January 2012|date=22 January 2012}}</ref> Other file hosting websites followed suit, including FileServe.com, FileJungle.com, Uploadstation.com, x7.to and 4shared.com, by shutting down, cancelling affiliate programs or allowing users to only download what they themselves uploaded.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyberlocker Ecosystem Shocked As Big Players Take Drastic Action|url=http://torrentfreak.com/cyberlocker-ecosystem-shocked-as-big-players-take-drastic-action-120123/|work=torrentfreak.com|accessdate=23 January 2012|date=23 January 2012}}</ref> Another large file-sharing website, Uploaded.to, ceased services for users accessing from United States-based IP addresses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://technologymob.com/2012/01/filesonic-and-uploaded-to-bow-out-in-light-of-recent-events/ |title=FileSonic and Uploaded.to bow out in light of recent events |publisher=Technologymob.com |date=23 January 2012 |accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref> [[BTJunkie]], a website indexing [[torrent file]]s, shut down voluntarily on 6 February 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://techland.time.com/2012/02/06/bittorrent-index-btjunkie-bites-the-dust/|title=BitTorrent Index BTjunkie Bites the Dust |work=Time |date=6 February 2012 |accessdate=8 February 2012}}</ref> The file hosting site Turbobit.net blocked access to U.S. visitors,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://torrentfreak.com/turbobit-net-blocks-us-visitors-after-megaupload-shutdown-120207/|title=Turbobit.net Blocks US Visitors After MegaUpload Shutdown|publisher=TorrentFreak.net |date=7 February 2012 |accessdate=8 February 2012}}</ref> and QuickSilverScreen, a site offering [[streaming media|streaming video]] links, closed on 7 February 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://torrentfreak.com/quicksilverscreen-streaming-site-calls-it-quits-120207/|title=QuickSilverScreen Streaming Links Site Calls It Quits|publisher=TorrentFreak.net |date=7 February 2012 |accessdate=8 February 2012}}</ref>
However, other file hosting companies felt no need to change, with [[MediaFire]]'s CEO Derek Labian saying that he and his file hosting company are not concerned by the Megaupload incident because "Megaupload was making a ridiculous amount of money with a ridiculously bad service... We don't have a business built on copyright infringement."<ref>22 January 2012, [https://venturebeat.com/2012/01/22/mediafire-megaupload-business-model-piracy/ MediaFire CEO: Unlike Megaupload, our business model isn’t built on piracy], CloudBeat</ref> A spokesperson for [[RapidShare]] similarly expressed a lack of concern, saying that "file hosting itself is a legitimate business", pointing out that Microsoft's [[OneDrive]] operates on a similar basis.<ref>20 January 2012, [https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2012/01/rapidshare-not-concerned-about-megaupload-takedown.ars RapidShare "not concerned" about Megaupload takedown], Ars Technica</ref>

{{Infobox rebbe | title = Kaliver Rebbe | image = Rav moshe sternbuch and kaliver rebbe.JPG | caption = The Kaliver Rebbe (left) with Rabbi [[Moishe Sternbuch]] | term = | full name = Menachem Mendel Taub | signature = | main work =''Kol Menachem'' | predecessor = | successor = | spouse1 = Chana Sarah Shapiro | issue1 = | spouse2 = Sheindel Malnik | issue2 = | dynastyname = [[Kaliv (Hasidic dynasty)|Kaliv]] | father = Rabbi Yehudah Yechiel Taub | mother = | birth_date = 1923 (95 years) | birth_place = [[Transylvania]] | death_date = | death_place = | date of burial = | place of burial = |}} '''Menachem Mendel Taub''' (born 1923) is the [[Rebbe]] of the [[Kaliv (Hasidic dynasty)|Kaliv]] [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidic]] [[List of Hasidic dynasties|dynasty]]. Born in [[Transylvania]] in 1923, he is seventh in a direct paternal line to the founder of the dynasty, Rabbi Yitzchak Izak of Kaliv, a disciple of the Rebbe Reb [[Elimelech of Lizhensk]].
His second cousin, Rabbi Moshe Taub, is the Kalover Rebbe of [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn|Williamsburg]], New York.<ref>Ehrlich, Aryeh. "Until the Last Yid". ''[[Mishpacha]]'', September 2, 2013, p. 68.</ref>
==Biography== Menachem Mendel Taub is the son of Rabbi Yehuda Yechiel Taub, the Rozler Rov, and son-in-law of Grand Rabbi Pinchos Shapiro, the Kechneyer Rebbe, scion of the [[Nadvorna (Hasidic dynasty)|Nadvorna]] dynasty. He had six brothers and sisters.<ref name=jp/> He married his first wife, Chana Sara Shapiro, before the start of World War II.<ref name=jp>{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/Jewish-World/Jewish-Features/Sparks-of-love-this-Lag-Baomer|first=Jeremy|last=Sharon|title=Sparks of Love This Lag Ba'omer|date=10 May 2012|accessdate=13 May 2014|work=[[The Jerusalem Post]]}}</ref>
In 1944, he was deported to [[Auschwitz concentration camp]], arriving there three days before [[Shavuot]]. While in Auschwitz, he was experimented upon by [[Josef Mengele]]. Because of "chemical burning experiments", he is unable to grow facial hair;<ref name=jp/> he is also unable to have children.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}} He was transferred from Auschwitz to the [[Warsaw Ghetto]] and the [[Breslau]] [[concentration camp]], and later to [[Bergen-Belsen concentration camp|Bergen-Belsen]]. Six months after the war ended, he reunited with his wife in [[Sweden]]. In 1947 they immigrated to the United States and settled in [[Cleveland]], Ohio.<ref name=jp/><ref>{{cite book |first=Meir|last=Halachmi|title=תולדות החסידות בארץ ישראל |trans-title=History of Hasidism in Israel|volume=1|pages=540–542}}</ref>
He and his wife [[Aliyah|immigrated]] to [[Israel]] in 1962.<ref name=jp/> The following year he founded Kiryas Kaliv in [[Rishon LeZion]].<ref>{{cite book |url={{Google books |id=iKDXAAAAMAAJ |plainurl=yes }} |script-title=he:החברה החרדית: מקורות, מגמות ותהליכים|trans-title=Haredi Society: Sources, Trends, and Processes|first=Menachem|last=Friedman|page=152|year=1991|publisher=[[Jerusalem Institute for Israel Studies]]|language=Hebrew|accessdate=13 May 2014}}</ref> The foundation stone was laid on 7 Adar 5723 (3 March 1963), the day of the [[Bereavement in Judaism#Yahrtzeit, Nahala|yahrtzeit]] of the founder of the dynasty, Grand Rabbi Yitzchak Isak Taub. Several years later he moved his headquarters to [[Bnei Brak]].<ref name=jp/> In 2004, the rebbe's court moved to [[Jerusalem]].<ref name=jp/>
==Activities== Since World War II, the Rebbe has actively spoken about the Holocaust and frequently invokes the memory of the Jewish martyrs. He has encouraged the recital of "[[Shema Yisrael]]" to memorialize Holocaust victims at the conclusion of religious events in Israel.<ref name=news>{{cite web |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/148876#.U3J96fmSzkU|title=Thousands of Jews Pray at Yosef's Tomb|first=Tzvi|last=Ben Gedalyahu|date=18 October 2011|accessdate=13 May 2014|work=[[Arutz Sheva|Israel National News]]}}</ref> He has also traveled to interact with millions of [[Jews]] by telling his story and encouraging the saying of "Shema Yisrael". He is also active in [[Orthodox Jewish outreach|Jewish outreach]] and conducts regular lectures for groups of professionals, including doctors and police officers. In addition, a network of [[kollel]]s, an encyclopedia project, and several other divisions of Kaliv have been founded.
In March 2014 he participated in the annual conference of the Rabbinical Congress of Europe, which met in [[Budapest]] to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the destruction of [[History of the Jews in Hungary|Hungarian Jewry]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lubavitch.com/news/article/2030765/European-Jewry-Anti-Semitism-Addressed-at-Rabbinical-Conference-in-Hungary.html|title=European Jewry, Anti-Semitism, Addressed at Rabbinical Conference in Hungary|first=Rena |last=Greenberg|date=25 March 2014|accessdate=13 May 2014|publisher=Lubavitch.com}}</ref> He delivered an emotion-laden speech in Hebrew, and switched to English to direct remarks to US President [[Barack Obama]] and Russian president [[Vladimir Putin]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vosizneias.com/159496/2014/03/25/budapest-in-moving-speech-at-holocust-commemoration-kalever-rebbe-warns-obama-and-putin-of-dangers-ahead/|title=Budapest - In Moving Speech At Holocaust Commemoration Kalever Rebbe Warns Obama And Putin Of Dangers Ahead|first=Sandy|last=Eller|date=25 March 2014|accessdate=13 May 2014|work=[[Vosizneias]]}}</ref>
==Personal life== Taub's first wife, Chana Sara, died in 2010.<ref name=jp/> On [[Lag BaOmer]] 2012, he remarried to 55-year-old Sheindel Malnik of [[Bnei Brak]].<ref name=jp/>

Chief superintendent of the [[Military Engineering Experimental Establishment]] }} '''Sir Millis Rowland Jefferis''' [[Order of the British Empire|KBE]] [[Military Cross|MC]] (9 January 1899 – 5 September 1963) was a British military officer who founded a special unit of the British [[Ministry of Supply]] which developed unusual weapons during the [[Second World War]]. ==Early career== Born at Merstham, Surrey on 9 January 1899,General Register Office entry of birth, Jan-Mar 1899, Croydon registration district, Volume 2a Page 278 Jefferis was educated at [[Tonbridge School]] and [[Royal Military Academy, Woolwich]]. From Woolwich he was commissioned into the [[Royal Engineers]] on 6 June 1918 and after passing through the [[Royal School of Military Engineering|School of Military Engineering]] at [[Chatham, Kent|Chatham]], he was posted to the First Field Squadron RE in the Rhine Army.''Sir Millis Jefferis New Weapons of War (Obituary)''. ''[[The Times]]'', 7 September 1963 p10 column E. In 1920 he went to India and served with the [[Madras Engineer Group|Queen's Own Madras Sappers and Miners]] in the Third Field Troop at Sialkot. In 1922 he went into the Works Services in India as garrison engineer at [[Kohat]] and then at [[Spina Khaisora|Khaisora]] which is today in [[Pakistan]]. He saw active service in the [[Waziristan campaign (1936–1939)|Waziristan Campaign]] where his main responsibility was the construction of roads. On 12 June 1923 he was awarded the [[Military Cross]], the citation read: {{quote|''The War Office, 12th June, 1923.'' His Majesty the KING has been graciously pleased to approve of the undermentioned rewards for distinguished service in the Field with the Razmak Force: — ''Awarded the Distinguished Service Order.'' Maj. Leslie Charles Bertram Deed, R.E. ''Awarded the Military Cross.'' Lt. Millis Rowland Jefferis, R.E. For gallantry and devotion to duty whilst reconnoitring ahead of the road construction parties on the Isha-Razmak road between May and December, 1922, and in the supervision of the work. The satisfactory progress of the road was due in great measure to their efforts and disregard of danger.{{London Gazette|issue=32833|pages=4133–4134|date=12 June 1923}}}} He then returned to Chatham and went to [[Cambridge University]]. In 1925 he returned to India and was placed on special duty at [[Kabul]] in the foreign and political department. In 1926 he returned to [[Nowshera, Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa|Nowshera]] as garrison engineer and spent several years in Works Services at [[Peshawar]] where he made full use of this engineering genius designing bridges. Also in 1925, he married Ruth Carolyne, daughter of G. E. Wakefield. They had three sons, two of whom went on to serve in the Royal Engineers. On 1 June 1929, Jefferis was promoted to [[captain (land)|captain]].{{London Gazette|issue=33500|page=3587|date=31 May 1929}} In 1934 he was posted to the [[Royal Bombay Sappers and Miners]] at Kirkee as a company commander in the training battalion. He returned to Britain in 1936 and joined the Twenty-third Field Company at [[Aldershot]]. Moving to the First Field Squadron, he stayed at Aldershot while the unit was being [[Armoured warfare|mechanised]]. While at Aldershot, Jefferis successfully raced horses and played [[Squash (sport)|squash]] competitively.''Point-To-Point Meetings – The Whaddon Chase''. ''[[The Times]]'' newspaper, 14 March 1938 p4 column E.''Squash Rackets – Army Championship ''. ''[[The Times]]'' newspaper, 9 November 1937 p8 column G. He was promoted [[major (United Kingdom)|major]] on 6 June 1938,{{London Gazette|issue=34517|supp=y|page=3638|date=9 May 1939}} and on 4 April 1939 he was appointed a [[staff officer|General Staff Officer, Grade 2]].{{London Gazette|issue=34624|page=3106|date=9 May 1939}} ==Second World War== ===Norway=== In 1940, Jefferis was sent to Norway, he returned to give a personal account of his activities to Prime Minister Winston Churchill who used his report to brief the War Cabinet: {{quote|sign=|source=|The Prime Minister gave the War Cabinet an account of the report which had been made personally to him by Major Jefferis. Major Jefferis had been sent out to Andalsnea with instructions to blow up the Western railway in Central Norway. He had accordingly gone down the railway line and joined Brigadier Morgan’s Brigade; but the Norwegians had categorically refused to allow him to carry out any demolitions. He had been present when Morgan’s Brigade had been engaged by the enemy. The Germans had attacked with artillery, tanks and armoured cars, which our troops had been without. Far more destructive of morale, however, had been the low-flying attacks with bombs and machine guns. Although the casualties had not been so great as from shell fire, the moral effect of seeing the aircraft coming, of being unable to take cover, of being able to observe the bomb dropping, and of the terrific explosion, had been overwhelming. Jefferis had eventually found himself with the Germans behind him. Picking up a sergeant and two privates, he had succeeded in making his way back to Andalsnes; and on the way he had managed to blow up the girders of two bridges on the German side. He estimated that it would take some three weeks to repair these. At Andalsenes the conditions of air attack had been such as to make it quite impossible to walk down to the jetty during daylight hours. He had spent a day in a sloop in the harbour at which thirty bombs had been aimed. None had hit, but the immunity of a ship under such conditions could only be, in Major Jefferis’s opinion, a matter of time, and he calculated that his life would probably not be more than three days. The general conclusion which he (the Prime Minister) drew from Major Jefferis’s account was that it was quite impossible for land forces to withstand complete air superiority of the kind which the Germans had enjoyed in Norway. This made it all the more imperative to the success of our operations at Narvik that we should establish air bases in that area, not only for fighters, but also for bombers.[[The National Archives]], [http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/catalogue/displaycataloguedetails.asp?CATLN=7&CATID=-4279405 CAB 65/7/1], [http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/documentsonline/details-result.asp?Edoc_Id=7965566 ''Conclusion of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10 Downing Street, SW1, on Wednesday, May 1, 1940 at 10:30 am''], pp. 5–6. (Free download available.)}} For his service in Norway, Jefferis was awarded the Norwegian [[War Cross with sword]],{{London Gazette|issue=35660|supp=y|page=3493|date=7 August 1942}} and [[Mentioned in Despatches]] for his efforts in the withdrawal from [[Lillehammer]].{{London Gazette|issue=35020|supp=y|pages=7200–7201|date=20 December 1940}}[http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/documentsonline/details-result.asp?Edoc_Id=7688597 Recommendations for honours and awards, Army—Image details—Jefferis, Millis Rowland—Mention in Despatches], ''DocumentsOnline'', [[The National Archives]] (fee usually required to view full original recommendation). Retrieved on 6 November 2008 ===MD1=== Jefferis started working on sabotage devices for the "Military Intelligence Research" (MIR). When MIR was combined with other ''hush-hush'' elements to form the [[Special Operations Executive|SOE]], Jefferis' unit was not included and it instead became a department in the Ministry of Defence; the only unit of the Minister of Defence (The Prime Minister, [[Winston Churchill]]) and was known as "[[MD1]]", ultimately based in a house called "The Firs" in Whitchurch near [[Aylesbury]] in Buckinghamshire England.Thomson, 1958, p63 The unit was responsible for the design, development and production of a number of unique special forces and regular munitions during the Second World War. It gained the nickname "Winston Churchill's toyshop". Jefferis was an explosives expert and engineer, but lacked the ability to manage men well. He was assisted in the management of MD1 by a wily assistant – Major [[Stuart Macrae (inventor)|Stuart Macrae]], whose book ''Winston Churchill's Toyshop'', is still one of the few published works on this unique unit. Over the period of the Second World War, MD1 was responsible for the introduction into service of a total of 26 different devices. Their designs include the [[PIAT]], the [[Sticky bomb]] and one of the first magnetic Limpet [[naval mines]]. Through the application of the Squash head and HEAT technology they had a role in the development and production of Lt-Col [[Stewart Blacker]]'s [[Blacker Bombard]], the PIAT (Blacker's smaller version of the bombard matched to a hollow charge warhead, [[Hedgehog (weapon)|Hedgehog]] (effectively an adaption of the Bombard spigot mortar principle working with the Navy's [[Directorate of Miscellaneous Weapons Development]]) and tank variants including the [[Armoured Vehicle Royal Engineers|AVRE]] with its "Flying Dustbin" 290mm Petard [[spigot mortar]],[http://www.remuseum.org.uk/articles/rem_article_assaultbridge.htm Royal Engineers Museum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100625161850/http://www.remuseum.org.uk/articles/rem_article_assaultbridge.htm |date=25 June 2010 }} and a bridge-laying tank. Jefferis developed the idea of the squash head further. His most ambitious project was a bomb designed to sink [[capital ship]]s, his ideas were put forward by himself and [[Lord Cherwell]] in 1944 and coincided with the Admiralty's interest in developing a homing bomb for use against the Japanese. The development of this weapon was supported by the Air Staff and MAP who allocated it a higher priority that any other anti-capital ship weapon. When the war ended, development of the 'Cherwell-Jefferis' bomb was continued under the code names ''Journey's End'' and ''[[Blue Boar (bomb)|Blue Boar]]''.Twigge 1996. pp. 104–105. Prime Minister Churchill became acquainted with then Major Jefferis in 1940 and regarded him as a "singularly capable and forceful man." He recommended a promotion to [[Lieutenant Colonel (United Kingdom)|lieutenant colonel]] so that Jefferis would have more authority. Jefferis received substantive promotion to this rank on 10 February 1944.{{London Gazette|issue=36576|supp=y|page=2977|date=20 June 1944}} Jefferis was promoted to [[Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (KBE) by Churchill in the [[1945 Prime Minister's Resignation Honours]], having previously been appointed a Commander of the Order (CBE).{{London Gazette|issue=37227|supp=y|pages=4183–4184|date=14 August 1945}} He was promoted to acting [[Major General (United Kingdom)|major general]] on 15 May 1945,{{London Gazette|issue=37236|supp=y|page=4274|date=21 August 1945}} and substantive [[colonel (United Kingdom)|colonel]] on 14 July 1945.{{London Gazette|issue=37245|supp=y|page=4377|date=28 August 1945}} He left the Ministry of Supply on 20 November 1945, reverting to the temporary rank of brigadier.{{London Gazette|issue=37419|supp=y|page=233|date=1 January 1946}} ==Later career== In 1945 Jefferis became deputy Engineer-in-Chief in India and 1947 he became Engineer-in-Chief in Pakistan, holding the temporary rank of major general. He was promoted to substantive [[brigadier]] on 1 November 1947,{{London Gazette|issue=38242|supp=y|page=2007|date=19 March 1948}} and returned to England on 2 January 1950{{London Gazette|issue=38922|supp=y|page=2617|date=26 May 1950}} to become Chief Superintendent of the Military Engineering Experimental Establishment, reverting to the rank of brigadier on 8 March 1950.{{London Gazette|issue=38854|supp=y|page=1151|date=7 March 1950}} He was made [[Aide de Camp|ADC to the King]] on 24 May 1951 and held that appointment until he retired on 18 August 1953, on his retirement he was granted the honorary rank of major-general.{{London Gazette|issue=39268|supp=y|page=3479|date=22 June 1951}}{{London Gazette|issue=39939|supp=y|page=4467|date=14 August 1953}} As an ADC, Jefferis took part in [[George VI of the United Kingdom|King George VI's]] funeral, and [[Queen Elizabeth II]]'s [[Coronation of the British monarch|Coronation Procession]]''Processions''. ''[[The Times]]'' newspaper, 1 June 1953 p19.{{London Gazette|issue=39575|supp=y|pages=3345–3351|date=17 June 1952}}{{London Gazette|issue=40020|supp=y|pages=6223–6227|date=17 November 1953 }} He died on 5 September 1963. == Ocean racing == Jefferis had a passion for ocean racing. In 1938, he built a 7-ton yacht at Aldershot called ''Prelude'' with another Royal Engineer officer and they sailed successfully both before and after the war.''Yacht Racing – The New Lloyd's''. ''[[The Times]]'' newspaper, 25 May 1948 p6 column B.''Sports in Brief – Ocean Racing''. {{Infobox artist |name = Pauline Smith |birth_name = Pauline Elizabeth Smith |birth_date = {{Birth date|1933|9|5|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Kenya]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|2017|3|19|1933|9|5|df=y}} |death_place = |nationality = British |movement = [[Mail art]] }} '''Pauline Elizabeth Smith''' (5 September 1933 – 19 March 2017) was a British provocateur and artist who specialised in [[mail art]]. In later life she became fascinated by astrology and the "charismatic appeal" of [[Adolf Hitler]]. She founded the Adolf Hitler Fan Club in order to test the limits of free speech and to provoke a reaction, which it did when the police raided her home. == Early life == Smith was born in [[Kenya]] on 5 September 1933. Her father was a telecommunications engineer. The family lived in Uganda and Egypt before arriving in the United Kingdom in 1945. Smith was educated at a convent school in St. Albans which she left at the age of 16 against the wishes of her mother. She worked as a florist, a window dresser and for the [[BBC]] as a secretary. Between 1962 and 1966 she took evening classes at [[Saint Martin's School of Art]] where she was taught by [[Anthony Caro]] and [[Elizabeth Frink]]. She took classes at the [[Chelsea School of Art]] in 1966–67 under [[Jeremy Moon]], [[Robyn Denny]] and [[Anthony Hill (artist)|Anthony Hill]].[https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/pauline-smith-obituary-m5xc7zxdc Pauline Smith.] ''[[The Times]]''. 12 June 2017. Retrieved 15 June 2017. {{subscription required}} She spent two years as a school teacher from 1970 but left due to disillusionment about British teaching conditions. == Art career == [[File:Sun & Moon, Pauline Smith, 2013.jpg|thumb|''Sun & Moon'', photograph, Pauline Smith, 2013.]] Smith's first solo exhibition was in 1969 and her photographs and paintings were also shown in London and New York. In the early 1970s she began to create mail art after she met [[Opal L. Nations]] and was invited to join the [[Global Infantilism]] group. She knew [[Anna Banana]], founder of ''Vile'' magazine, and [[Bill Gaglione]]. Her work had a strong anti-establishment theme and her regular despatches included ''Lost Marbles Dump'', which commented on property developers in [[Chelsea, London|Chelsea]], and ''A Present From Belfast'' about the [[conflict in Northern Ireland]]. In 1974{{cite book|author=Reed, S. Alexander.|title=Assimilate: A critical history of industrial music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9sUVDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA200|year=2013|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|location=New York|isbn=978-0-19-983258-3|page=200}} she founded the Adolf Hitler Fan Club, of which she was probably the only member, and around the same time created an Adolf Hitler Memorial Fund collecting tin, in order to test the limits of free speech, provoke a reaction, and make an ironic and satirical comment on life in [[Labour government, 1974–1979|pre-Thatcher]] Britain. In 1977 she issued mail art signed "[[Heinrich Himmler|H Himmler]]".[http://www.lomholtmailartarchive.dk/texts/anna-banana-excerpts-from-a-mail-artists-diary/1977-07-22-smith-pauline Open Letter from Pauline Smith 1977-07-22.] Lomholt Mail Art Archive. Retrieved 20 June 2017. Postal emissions relating to the Hitler fan club resulted in a police raid on her home. In 1983, she explained in her ''c.v.'':
The ADOLF HITLER FAN CLUB was intended to be an analogy for the week-kneed [''sic''] British Governments since 1945 and was stimulated by local Chelsea politics regarding landlords/tenants/development/tourism, in which I was interested in the early seventies. Of course, this was not the only factor involved but it was the most pressing. The country is a mess and nothing gets any better. What I feel about the current situation will take several years more to express through my art. For the immediate present I am preoccupied with Adolf Hitler's involvement in the occult, the mediumistic nature of his public speaking and the mystery of his charismatic appeal to the multitudes ... Adolf Hitler remained the subject of my painting as he had been of my Mailart and I continue to paint about him because everything that has happened in this country since his death has been a reaction against him. He is the biggest influence on this country this century.[https://www.stewarthomesociety.org/ass/ma.htm THE ASSAULT ON CULTURE CHAPTER 13 (pages 69-73) MAIL ART.] stewarthomesociety.org Retrieved 18 June 2017.
In 2006 she distributed ''Tombs of the Last (Species)'' to all [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|members of Parliament]] followed by ''SPECIES TOMBS'' circulated to all MPs in 2008. In 2013 she produced ''Sun and Moon'' as a commentary on military action in the Middle East which featured a Sun and Moon, a carousel horse, and a tank against a split background with an Arabic language newspaper in the top half and a deconstructed American flag below. She used antique black and white cameras to produce her mailart which she replaced with a modern colour camera in 1998, and colour photography became her main medium for a time, taking pictures that she said were "inspired by ancient monuments, cultures, myths and flint simulacra gathered on Brighton beach which also could have interested our ancient ancestors."[https://www.axisweb.org/p/paulinesmith/#info Biography.] Axisweb. Retrieved 18 June 2017. ''Extinctions'' was a series of 14 colour Xerox prints of inscribed photographs inspired by her interest in nature and animal forces. She created oil paintings from Second World War photographs and carved some ivory figures in order to undermine demand for the material. == Personal life == [[Astrology]] played an important part in her life and her art from the early 1980s. She was greatly affected by [[Richard Houck]]'s book ''The Astrology of Death'' (1994) and later produced astrological charts analysing the death of [[Alexander Litvinenko]] in 2006[https://web.archive.org/web/20170716102511/https://www.astrologicalassociation.com/pages/publications/transit/march07/litvinenko.htm Litvinenko’s Death Transits.] Pauline Smith, ''Transit'', March/April 2007. Retrieved 16 July 2017. and the [[2007 financial crisis]].[https://www.astrologicalassociation.com/pages/publications/transit/nov08/finances.php The Financial Crisis & The UK: Some Thoughts.] Pauline Smith, ''Transit'', November/December 2008. Retrieved 16 July 2017. She was often in ill-health and in 1990 was diagnosed with [[myalgic encephalomyelitis]] (ME) after having suffered periods of illness since the 1960s. Those who knew her described her as deeply reserved. She never married. == Death and legacy == Smith died after a long illness on 19 March 2017. The [[Tate Gallery]] has around 30 boxes of her art and correspondence including her Adolf Hitler Memorial Fund collecting tin.[http://www.tate.org.uk/context-comment/articles/we-have-mail We have mail.] Lawrence Norfolk, Tate Gallery, 1 May 2006. {{About|a group of five members}} {{Unreferenced|date=July 2009}}
A '''quintet''' is a group containing five members. It is commonly associated with musical groups, such as a [[string quintet]], or a group of five singers, but can be applied to any situation where five similar or related objects are considered a single unit.
==Overview== In [[european classical music|classical instrumental music]], any additional instrument (such as a [[piano]], [[clarinet]], [[oboe]], etc.) joined to the usual [[string quartet]] (two [[violin]]s, a [[viola]], and a [[cello]]), gives the resulting ensemble its name, such as "[[piano quintet]]", "[[clarinet quintet]]", etc. A piece of music written for such a group is similarly named.
The standard [[wind quintet]] consists of one player each on [[Western concert flute|flute]], [[oboe]], [[clarinet]], [[bassoon]], and [[French horn|horn]], while the standard [[brass quintet]] has two [[trumpet]]s, [[French horn|horn]], [[trombone]], and [[tuba]]. Other combinations, however, are sometimes found.
In [[jazz music]], a quintet is group of five players, usually consisting of two of any of the following instruments, [[guitar]], [[trumpet]], [[saxophone]], [[clarinet]], [[flute]] or [[trombone]] in addition to traditional [[jazz trio]] – [[piano]], [[double bass]], [[Drum kit|drums]].
In some modern bands there are quintets formed from the same family of instruments with various voices, as an all-[[brass instrument|brass]] ensemble, or all [[saxophone]]s, in [[soprano saxophone|soprano]], [[alto saxophone|alto]], [[baritone saxophone|baritone]], and [[bass (instrument)|bass]], and sometimes [[double bass]].
Many rock, pop, and metal bands are made up of five people, normally consisting of two [[guitarist]]s, a [[bassist]], a [[drummer]], and a [[lead vocalist]]. This is normally considered to the maximum size of most bands. However, several bands like [[Linkin Park]], [[Slipknot (band)|Slipknot]], [[Guns N' Roses]], and [[DragonForce]] have more than 5 band members. Having more than five members is mostly uncommon in rock and pop music.{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}}
It is becoming increasingly common in [[a cappella]] and [[barbershop music]] circles to use the fifth voice as vocal percussionist, with the remainder being a traditional SATB ([[soprano]] [[alto]] [[tenor]] [[bass (voice type)|bass]]) quartet, or perhaps SSAA or TTBB.{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}}
==Notable quintets== === Classical music === * [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]]: [[Quintet for Piano and Winds (Mozart)|Quintet for Piano and Winds]] [[Köchel-Verzeichnis|K.]] 452 (oboe, clarinet, bassoon and horn) (1784) * Mozart: [[Clarinet Quintet (Mozart)|Quintet for clarinet and strings]] in A major, [[Köchel-Verzeichnis|K.]] 581 (1789) * [[Anton Reicha|Reicha]]: [[wind quintet]]s, among the first for the medium (starting in 1811) * [[Franz Schubert|Schubert]]: [[Trout Quintet|Piano Quintet]] in A major, D.667 (1819), popularly known as the 'Trout Quintet', based on his [[Lied]] "[[Die Forelle]]" ("the trout"). The piece is scored for violin, viola, cello, bass instead of an additional violin, and piano, unlike the usual arrangement of the piano quintet * Schubert: [[String Quintet (Schubert)|String Quintet]] in C major, Op.163 (D.956, 1828) * [[Robert Schumann|Schumann]]: [[Piano Quintet (Schumann)|Piano Quintet]] in E-flat, Op.44 (1842) * [[Johannes Brahms|Brahms]]: [[Piano Quintet (Brahms)|Piano Quintet]] in F minor, Op.34 (1862); [[String Quintet No. 1 (Brahms)|String Quintet]] in F major, Op.88 (1882); [[Clarinet Quintet (Brahms)|Clarinet Quintet]] in B minor, Op. 115 (1891) * [[Antonín Dvořák|Dvorak]]: Piano Quintets in A major, Op.5 (1872), and [[Piano Quintet No. 2 (Dvořák)|Op. 81]] (1887), heavily influenced by both the Schubert and Schumann piano quintets * [[Georges Bizet|Bizet]]: opera ''[[Carmen]]'' contains a particularly engaging quintet (not always performed), by singers playing some of the [[smuggling|smugglers]] (1873–74) * [[Anton Bruckner|Bruckner]]: [[String Quintet (Bruckner)|String Quintet]] in F major (1879) * [[Dmitri Shostakovich|Shostakovich]]: [[Piano Quintet (Shostakovich)|Piano Quintet]] in G minor, Op.57 (1940)
===Jazz=== * 'The Greatest Concert Ever.' Jazz quintet. [[Charlie Parker]], alto saxophone; [[Dizzy Gillespie]], trumpet; [[Bud Powell]], piano; [[Charles Mingus]], bass; and [[Max Roach]], drums. [[Massey Hall]], [[Toronto]], Canada. (May 15, 1953) This concert took place against all odds: Bud Powell was drunk; Charlie Parker, identified as "Charlie Chan" in the original notes, played on a plastic alto saxophone; and Dizzy Gillespie would disappear offstage to check on the status of the first [[Rocky Marciano]]-[[Jersey Joe Walcott]] heavyweight championship match. * [[Miles Davis Quintet|Miles Davis' First and Second 'great' Quintets]]: ** The First Great Quintet (1955–1958) [[Miles Davis]], trumpet; [[John Coltrane]], tenor saxophone; [[Red Garland]], piano; [[Paul Chambers]], bass; [[Philly Joe Jones]], drums. ** The Second Great Quintet (1964–1968) [[Miles Davis]], trumpet; [[Wayne Shorter]], tenor saxophone; [[Herbie Hancock]], piano; [[Ron Carter]], bass; [[Tony Williams (drummer)|Tony Williams]], drums.
