{{Infobox person | name = Ruby Garrard Woodson | image = RubyAtBrownU1975.jpg | caption = Ruby G. Woodson, founder of Cromwell Academy and of Florida Academy of African American Culture, {{circa|1975}} | birth_date = {{Birth date|1931|06|22}} | birth_place = [[Houston County, Alabama|Houston County]], [[Alabama]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2008|02|08|1931|06|22}} | education = {{Plainlist| * [[Florida A & M University]], BS * [[American University]], MA }} | occupation = [[Educator]], chemistry teacher | children = William G. Woodson }}
'''Ruby Garrard Woodson''' (June 22, 1931 – February 8, 2008) was an [[educator]] and chemistry teacher, the founder of the ''Cromwell Academy'' in [[Washington, D. C.]], and the founder of the ''Florida Academy of African American Culture'' in [[Sarasota, Florida]].
She was born in [[Houston County, Alabama]], but raised in Sarasota. Her mother, Ella Mae Garrard (later, Singleton) worked as a maid and later owned a small country store. Her father, David Garrard, was a farmer, and later a [[circus]] [[roustabout]]. She had one child, William G. Woodson.
At the age of fifteen, she was the [[valedictorian]] of her class of 1947 when she was graduated from [[Booker High School (Florida)|Booker High School]] in Sarasota.
At the age of nineteen, in June 1951 Woodson was awarded her [[bachelor of science]] degree in [[chemistry]] from [[Florida A & M University]] in [[Tallahassee, Florida]]. She received her master of arts degree in education from [[American University]] in Washington, D.C. in 1960. Her masters thesis was entitled, ''Some Effects of the Atomic Era on the Teaching of High School Chemistry in the United States''.
== Breaking racial barrier at Sarasota library ==
In 1957, while she was on a vacation in her hometown of Sarasota and researching materials for completion of her master's degree, Ruby Woodson was refused entry to the public library in Sarasota. She made a formal objection to her treatment that she took to city and county government officials. Her efforts led to the elimination of racial barriers to community services paid for by the taxation of all residents. Soon the vestiges of [[racial segregation|segregation]] began to fall in Sarasota and all residents were granted access to the library.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sarasota.granicus.com/DocumentViewer.php?file=9e08dcc6246d3eeaa28e9d54f40c1104.pdf&view=1|title=Minutes Of The Regular Sarasota City Commission Meeting Of March 3, 2008|last=|first=|date=2008-03-03|website=City of Sarasota|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Cromwell Academy founded ==
[[Image:Ruby Garrard Woodson - memorial resolution by Sarasota Florida.JPG|thumb|Memorial resolution honoring the contributions and achievements of Ruby Garrard Woodson]] She spent thirteen years teaching chemistry and physics in the Washington, D.C. public school system before founding ''Cromwell Academy'', a private [[secondary school]] to serve [[gifted]] [[minority group|minority]] students in the district. The academy was founded in 1973 in a church annex and soon was sending many of its students to classes at [[Georgetown University]] and [[Howard University]] for credits toward their secondary diplomas. The inspiration for the name of the academy was [[Otelia Cromwell]], an educator who was the first black woman awarded a Ph.D. by [[Yale University]]. A reputation developed quickly by the academy for its academic achievements, attracting the enrollment of their children by prominent people as well as the gifted and aspiring members of disadvantaged groups whose teachers advised application to the academy. [[Bill Cosby]] sent his son, Ennis, and the president of [[Venezuela]] sent his daughter.
Woodson was a pivotal figure in the day-to-day administration of the academy and fulfilled many other roles such as college placement adviser, guidance counselor, as well as instructor. Initial difficulties encountered in operating expenses often were resolved by donations from Woodson's personal savings.
The student body of the academy was small and familial. Often, instruction in life skills also fell to Woodson, who helped the students with financing as well as handling personal issues and later, negotiating such things as the purchase of automobiles and houses. Donations were sought to develop a scholarship program to assist many of the students. Woodson had overcome [[dyslexia]] in her efforts to excel and was able to provide special insights to children coping with similar hurdles. She inspired the students with her own high standards of ethics and morality and helped them develop personal discipline and self-respect. She taught them how to make applications to colleges appropriate to their interests and abilities and to apply for scholarships.
The students from the academy gained entrance to the best academic institutions in the country and soon Woodson’s students were awarded baccalaureate and advanced degrees form [[Columbia University]], [[Mount Holyoke College]], [[Smith College]], [[Yale University]], and [[Vassar College]]. The academy became recognized for academic excellence.
One 1979 graduate of the academy, Lisa S. Martin, later was graduated from Yale University and Emory University and is a practicing psychologist in Maryland. She attests to the power Woodson had to inspire her students, making them feel able to meet any type of academic challenge and motivating them to win acceptance at the institutions of their choice, be it Ivy League, the big ten, or top southern colleges.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/article/20080214/NEWS/802140326|title=Educator broke down racial barriers in Sarasota|last=Zaloudek|first=Mark|date=2008-02-14|website=|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-07}}</ref> Woodson's achievements were lauded in the [[Washington Post]] and by the [[United States Department of Education]].
== Retirement to Sarasota ==
In 1989 Ruby Woodson retired to Sarasota, but immersed herself in the affairs of the community. She participated in many cultural and civic activities, from the Asolo Center for the Performing Arts and Habitat for Humanity to the United Way as well as in local and regional long-range planning charrettes. She ultimately was moved to found the Florida Academy for African-American Culture (FAAC), an institution dedicated to educational advancement and cultural preservation with a special emphasis on children from pre-school through high school.
She was appointed to the county library advisory board and was among those who brought a branch of the library to the Newtown neighborhood, the section of the city where she had been raised, so a library would be within walking distance for the children of that area. The United Way named Ruby Woodson among the twelve ''Women of Community Impact'' in Sarasota County.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/heraldtribune/obituary.aspx?n=ruby-garrard-woodson&pid=103324740|title=Ruby Garrard Woodson's Obituary on Herald Tribune|website=Herald Tribune|access-date=2016-07-07}}</ref>
== Florida Academy for African American Culture founded ==
After her return to Sarasota, Woodson founded another educational institution in that community, the ''Florida Academy for African American Culture''.
The historic home of a prominent black family, the ''Pearl and Grover Koons House'', was purchased, listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]], and developed as a museum with a library, the African-American Culture Research Center and Library, to enhance the educational opportunities of the children of the community. It had classrooms for gifted pre-school and school-age students in an adjacent building.
The academy sponsored [[Public speaking|oratory]] and [[essay]] contests, awarding prizes to students participating in its Black History events. Its library donated books to local students, churches, and day-care centers.<ref>[http://www.discoverblackflorida.com/index.asp?CommandSites=detail&SiteID=68] {{Dead link|date=July 2016}}</ref> Every Saturday free books were given to interested children coming to the academy.
==Focus on reading to inspire children==
An avid reader from her youth, Ruby Woodson emphasized the importance of developing reading skills in children and encouraging them to read about all things that interest them. She credited her father and Ethel Reid Hays, her first teacher, for encouraging her interest in reading.
{{quotation|text=I believe that learning to read at a young age and reading everything (as I did) makes all of the difference in the life of a child.<ref>[http://www.familyheritagehousemuseum.com/ ]</ref>|sign=Ruby G. Woodsen|source=}}
The quote above is from a biography of Ruby Woodson assembled and kept on file by the [[Family Heritage House Museum]] in Manatee County, Florida; the museum is on the campus of the State College of Florida (formerly Manatee Community College). The file includes an undated article published by the United Way of Sarasota County entitled, ''Ruby Woodson'', that contains this quote.

{{Infobox scientist | name = Shahrzad Mojab | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Shiraz]], [[Iran]] | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = Iranian | fields = Impact of war, displacement and violence on women’s learning and education. | workplaces = [[University of Windsor]]
[[Ryerson University]]
[[Concordia University (Quebec)|Concordia University]]
[[University of Toronto]] | alma_mater = [[Allameh Tabatabai University|College of Translation, Tehran]]
[[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] | thesis_title = The state and university: The ''Islamic Cultural Revolution'' in the institutions of higher education of Iran, 1980-1987 | thesis_url = http://www.ideals.illinois.edu/bitstream/handle/2142/22697/9210922.pdf | thesis_year = 1991 | doctoral_advisor = Dr. Steve Tozer | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[Royal Society of Canada]] Award in Gender Studies | signature = | signature_alt = | website = {{URL|http://www.oise.utoronto.ca/lhae/Faculty_Staff/1508/Shahrzad_Mojab.html}} | footnotes = | spouse = [[Amir Hassanpour]] }} '''Shahrzad Mojab''' is an academic activist and professor, teaching at the Department of Leadership, Higher and Adult Education and Women and Gender Studies Institute, at the [[University of Toronto]]. Shahrzad has been living in Canada since 1986 with her lifelong partner, colleague and comrade, [[Amir Hassanpour]], and their son, Salah. == Education and career == Mojab was born in [[Shiraz]], Iran.{{cite web|url=http://www.wworld.org/archive/archive.asp?ID=402|title=War and Motherhood}} She obtained her [[Bachelor of Arts]] in 1977 in [[Iran]] in the [[English language]]; her [[Master of Arts]] in Comparative Education and Administration, Higher and Continuing Education in 1979 and her [[Ph.D.]] in Educational Policy Studies and Women's Studies in 1991 both at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]]. She spent four years (1979-1983) in post-revolutionary Iran, where she became active in the left movement, women’s movement and the Kurdish autonomous movement. Before joining the University of Toronto in 1996, Shahrzad taught and worked at [[University of Windsor]], [[Ryerson University]] and at [[Concordia University (Quebec)|Concordia University]]. ==Research== Mojab's areas of research and teaching include education policy studies; gender, state, diaspora and [[transnationality]]; women, war, militarization and violence; women, war and learning; women political prisoners in the Middle East; transnational women's organizations; [[feminism]], anti-racism, [[colonialism]] and imperialism; Marxist-feminism and learning; adult education in comparative and global perspectives.{{cite book | title = Power in Practice: Adult Education and the Struggle for Knowledge and Power in Society | first = Ronald M. | last = Cervero | first2 = Arthur L. | last2 = Wilson | last3 =Associates | publisher = Wiley Default | year = 2001 | isbn = 0-7879-4729-6 | pages = xxix}} Her approach to the study of race, gender, class, nationality, transnationality, and ethnicity is informed by Marxist feminist dialectical, and historical materialism approach. She is critical of theoretical frameworks which treat race, gender, and class atomistically, and reduce them to the domains of discourse, text, language, or identity. She critiques monopolies of knowledge and power in education, and advocates dialogical and inclusive pedagogical practices. Mojab's research has been published on [[Islamic feminism]], minority women in academe, diversity and academic freedom in Canadian and Iranian universities, [[adult education]] and civil society in the [[Middle East]], feminism and [[nationalism]], state-university relation, and women's access to higher education. Her publications include, among others, articles and book chapters which have appeared in periodicals such as ''International Journal of Lifelong long Education''; ''Feminist Review''; ''Canadian Woman Studies Journal''; ''[[Journal of Middle East Women's Studies]]''; ''Journal of Ethnicities''; ''Resources for Feminist Research''; ''The Canadian Journal for the Study of Adult Education''; ''Adult Education Quarterly: A Journal of Research and Theory; Studies in Continuing Education''; ''Al-Raida Magazine'' (Institute for Women’s Studies in the Arab World); ''Pakistan Journal of Women’s Studies: Alam-e-Niswan''; ''Journal of Race, Gender, and Class''; and ''Atlantis: A Women’s Studies Journal''. Shahrzad writes in Persian and Kurdish and her work is translated into Arabic, French, German, Kurdish, Turkish, and Swedish. She is the editor of ''Marxism and Feminism'' (2015); ''Women, War, Violence, and Learning'' (2010); ''Women of a Non-State Nation: The Kurds'' (2001, second printing 2003). She co-edited with Sara Carpenter ''Educating from Marx: Race, Gender and Learning'' (2012), with Nahla Abdo, ''Violence in the Name of Honour: Theoretical and Political Challenges'' (2004), with Himani Bannerji and Judith Whitehead, ''Of Property and Propriety: The Role of Gender and Class in Imperialism and Nationalism'' (2001), and with Afsaneh Hojabri ''Women of Iran: A Subject bibliography'' and ''Two Decades of Iranian Women’s Studies in Exiles: A Subject Bibliography'' [in Farsi], both published by the Iranian Women’s Studies Foundation. She has been the guest editor of the special issue of ''Comparative Studies of South Asia, Africa, and the Middle East Journal'', on ''Gender and Empire (''Summer 2010) and on ''Dissent: The Politics and Poetics of Women’s Resistance'' (2012); ''International Journal of Lifelong Education'', on ''Women, War and Learning; and Resources for Feminist Research, on War and Militarization.'' Professor Mojab has created two research websites as an archival space for relevant resource for the research and as a tool for the dissemination of knowledge. The websites are: ''[http://www.oise.utoronto.ca/marxfem/index.html Marxism and Feminism: Research, Teaching, and Praxis]'' and ''[http://www.womenpoliticlprisoners.com The Art of Resistance in the Middle East]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}''. In recent years, Shahrzad has attempted to diversify the dissemination of her research results. Together with [http://www.shahrzadarshadi.com Shahrzad Arshadi], feminist filmmaker and photographer committed to social justice and human rights, she has produced two documentaries. ''Samjana: Memoirs and Resistance'' is based on her research about women in post-war Nepal, their role in the peace process, as well as the role of women’s NGOs in building sustainable peace. This documentary is filmed and directed by Shahrzad Arshadi. ''Talking Prison, Creating Art and Making Justice'' (2010) is a documentary based on an-art based project funded by the Ontario Arts Council and Toronto Arts Council called ''Words, Colour and Movement''. ''Behind the Stained Walls'' (2011) is dance representation of ''Words, Colour and Movement'' project. ''Dancing of Change'' (2015) a documentary which is filmed and directed by Shahrzad Arshadi is based on Shahrzad Mojab’s decades of research and work with Kurdish women. It captures their dreams and desires for a just world, which they seek in socialism and secularism. Her current research project is: ''Remembering Not to Forget'' is a Digital Storytelling Project telling the stories of former political prisoners-narrating state violence and telling tales of humanity, hope, and resistance. Using storytelling and digital techniques, participants will work one-on-one with artists and facilitators to tell stories, focusing on a particular time, place, space, theme, and moments of imprisonment. These stories include digital images, texts, recorded audio narrations, video clips and/or music. ==Awards and positions== Professor Mojab is the former Director of the Women and Gender Institute at the University of Toronto (2003-2008). She is also the past-President of the Canadian Association for the Studies of Adult Education. She is the recipient of several awards, including the 2008 Distinguished Contribution to Graduate Teaching Award at the University of Toronto. In 2006 she was named Noted Scholar in the Faculty of Education, University of British Columbia. In the same year the Student Administrative Council (SAC) of the University of Toronto recognized her commitments to equity and social justice by giving her the SAC Certificate. Shahrzad was the first prize winner in the Women’s WORLD writing contest, “Women’s Voices in War Zones” in 2003 as well as being recognized as the Distinguished Visitor at the University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada. ==Books== *{{cite book | editor-first = Shahrzad | editor-last = Mojab | title = Marxism and Feminism | location = London | publisher = Zed Books | year = 2015}} *{{cite book | {{no footnotes|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox person | name =Shinobu Orikuchi | image = Orikuchi.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1887|2|11}} | birth_place = {{JPN}} [[Osaka]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1953|9|3|1887|2|11}} | death_place = | restingplace = | othername = 折口 信夫 (a pen name:釋 迢空) | occupation = [[ethnologist]], [[linguistics|linguist]], [[folklorist]], [[novelist]], and [[poet]] | yearsactive = | spouse = | relatives = }} {{nihongo|'''Shinobu Orikuchi'''|折口 信夫|Orikuchi Shinobu|11 February 1887–3 September 1953}}, also known as {{nihongo|'''Chōkū Shaku'''|釋 迢空|''Shaku Chōkū''}}, was a [[Japanese people|Japanese]] [[ethnologist]], [[linguistics|linguist]], [[folklorist]], [[novelist]], and [[poet]]. As a disciple of [[Kunio Yanagita]], he established an original academic field named {{nihongo|"Orikuchiism"|折口学|Orikuchigaku}}, which is a mixture of Japanese folklore, Japanese classics, and [[Shinto|Shintō]]. He produced many works in a diversity of fields covering the history of literature, folkloric performing arts, folklore itself, [[Japanese language]], the classics study, Shintōology, ancient study, and so on. [[Yukio Mishima]] once called him the "Japanese [[Walter Pater]]".
==Biography== Orikuchi was born in the former [[Nishinari]], [[Osaka|Ōsaka]] (now part of [[Naniwa-ku, Osaka]]). After graduating with a degree in [[Japanese literature]] from [[Kokugakuin University]] in 1910, he started to teach [[Japanese language|Japanese]] and Chinese classics at junior high schools. In 1919, he was employed as a part-time instructor in Kokugakuin University. In 1922, he was promoted to professor. In 1924, he was hired as a professor at [[Keio University]] as well; afterward, he taught at two different universities until he died. As a poet, he and [[Kitahara Hakushu]] established a [[Tanka (poetry)|tanka]] magazine called ''Nikkō'' ("Sunshine") in 1924. In 1925, he published {{nihongo|''Between the Sea and the Mountains''|海山の間|Umi Yama no Aida}}, his first tanka book, which is highly estimated.
In 1934, he received a [[Doctor of Philosophy|doctorate]] for his study on the ''[[Man'yōshū]]''. He also established the {{Nihongo|Japan Folklorists Society|日本民俗協会}}. As a folklorist, Yanagita was known for rejecting every sexual subject; Orikuchi, in contrast, was very open-minded to these matters. He became a model for the protagonist in Mishima's short story {{Nihongo|''Mikumano Mōde''|三熊野詣}}, while his novel ''Shisha no Sho'' was the basis for a [[The Book of the Dead (film)|film]] by [[Kihachiro Kawamoto]].
==Major works== *{{Nihongo|''Umi Yama no Aida''|海やまのあひだ|"Between The Sea And The Mountains"}} – Tanka book *{{Nihongo|''Haru no Kotobure''|春のことぶれ|"The Spring Forerunner"}} – Tanka book *{{Nihongo|''Shisha no Sho''|死者の書|"The Book of the Dead"}} – Novel *{{Nihongo|''Kodai Kenkyū''|古代研究|"The Ancient Study"}} – Treatise on folklore and literature in ancient Japan *{{Nihongo|''Kabuki San''|かぶき讃|"Viva Kabuki"}} – [[Kabuki]] review

[[No Commercial Value]] | website = }} '''Scott Sturgeon''', also known as '''Stza Crack''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|t|ɪ|z|ə}} {{respell|STIZ|ə}}; born March 4, 1976), is a musician who has fronted several [[ska-punk]] [[band (music)|bands]] in the [[New York City]] area, the best known being [[Choking Victim]] and [[Leftöver Crack]]. The stage name Stza is a tribute to the [[Wu-Tang Clan]], in which the members would take their stage names from the [[Supreme Alphabet]] of the [[Five Percent Nation]], such as GZA (God ZigZagZig Allah) and RZA (Ruler ZigZagZig Allah) - Stza's name would therefore be ''Self Truth ZigZagZig Allah''. ==Early life== Stza was raised in New York by his mother, who he classified as an "over-protective [[Jewish]] mom". He rarely saw his biological father, and his stepfather committed [[suicide]].[http://thoughtcatalog.com/2011/an-interview-with-stza-crack-of-leftover-crack-and-sfh/ Lin, Tao - Thought Catalog - Interviews- Leftover Crack] As a teenager, he dropped out of high school, ran away from home and began riding freight trains.[http://www.thepunksite.com/interviews.php?page=leftovercrack Butler, Roya - The Punk Site - Interviews - Leftover Crack] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081205030513/http://www.thepunksite.com/interviews.php?page=leftovercrack |date=2008-12-05 }} Since the age of 16, Stza has been arrested several times, mainly for shoplifting.[http://betterpropaganda.com/content.aspx?id=179 Better Propaganda - Leftover Crack interview] ==Music career== In 1990, Stza and a friend of his, [[Alec Baillie]], formed No Commercial Value, which later evolved into [[Choking Victim]] and then again into [[Leftöver Crack]]. Although many members of these bands have come and gone, Stza remained a constant figure, writing the vast majority of the lyrics and music and becoming the bands' self-appointed spokesperson. Stza is also associated with the band Morning Glory through Leftöver Crack member, [[Ezra Kire]].[http://www.rockzone.com/interviews/loc.shtml Rockzone: Interviews: Leftover Crack] In 2005, he collaborated with [[Mischief Brew]] on a song for their first full-length album, [[Smash The Windows]]. In 2005, he played solo (doing acoustic shows) and in a new band, [[Crack Rock Steady Seven]], featuring members of [[The Infested]] in [[Europe]]. 2006 saw him in [[Mexico City]] forming another regional Crack Rocksteady Seven, the CRS7mx featuring members of [[Niño Zombi]]. In the fall of 2006 he returned to the United States and toured with Leftöver Crack, their tour with [[Citizen Fish]] was dubbed Cracktoberfest 2006. Most recently Stza has been involved in the creation of another punk/ska band, this time with members of Casa de Chihuahua, The Slackers, and The Degenerics (Nico do Gaillo, Ara Babajian and Frank Piegaro respectively) called "[[Star Fucking Hipsters]]". Star Fucking Hipsters' debut album was released September 30, 2008 on the [[Fat Wreck Chords]] label. Their second album, "Never Rest In Peace", was released on October 20, 2009 on the [[Alternative Tentacles]] label. Their new album, titled "From the Dumpster to the Grave" was released on October 11, 2011 on Fat Wreck Chords during a record release show at Europa in Brooklyn, New York.{{facebook|starf.ckinghipsters|Star F*cking Hipsters}} ==Personal life== Stza, along with other members of [[Leftöver Crack]], has at times resided at 155 [[Avenue C (Manhattan)|Avenue C]], better known as [[C-Squat]].[http://crackrocksteady.info/loc/interviews/rag_mag_2002.html Rag Magazine - Leftover Crack interview] He is [[vegetarian]].{{cite web|accessdate=September 7, 2018|url=http://www.punktastic.com/interviews/leftover-crack-4/|publicationdate=September 10, 2006|title=LEFTOVER CRACK|first=Paul|last=Savage|website=Punktastic.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140709085730/http://www.punktastic.com/interviews/leftover-crack-4/|archivedate=July 9, 2014}} ==Discography== ===Full lengths=== ;With Choking Victim *''[[No Gods, No Managers]]'' - (1999) ;With Leftover Crack *''[[Mediocre Generica]]'' - (2001) *''[[Fuck World Trade]]'' - (2004) *''[[Constructs of the State]]'' - (2015) ;With Star Fucking Hipsters *''[[Until We're Dead]]'' - (2008) *''[[Never Rest in Peace]]'' - (2009) *''[[From the Dumpster to the Grave]]'' - (2011) ===EPs=== *''Rock the 40 Oz.'' - (May 8, 2000) *''Shoot the Kids at School'' - (2000) *''[[Rock the 40 Oz: Reloaded]]'' - (July 16, 2004) ===Splits=== *''Baby Jesus Sliced Up in the Manger'' (as the Crack Rock Steady 7, with F-Minus), HellBent Records, 2001. *''Leftover Crack / [[Citizen Fish]] Split 7"'' (with Citizen Fish), [[Fat Wreck Chords]], 2006. *[[Deadline (split album)]] (with Citizen Fish), [[Fat Wreck Chords]], March 6, 2007. (LP on [[Alternative Tentacles]]) ===Compilations=== *''Give 'Em the Boot II'', (Crack City Rockers[Demo]) [[Hellcat Records]], 1999. *''Punk Rawk Explosion 6'', (Nazi White Trash), ?, 2003. *''Give 'Em the Boot III'', (Atheist Anthem) [[Hellcat Records]], 2002. *''Go Kart vs. the Corporate Giant Vol. 3'', (Rock The 40oz) [[Go Kart Records]], 2002. *''2003 Sampler'', (So Ya Wanna Be A Cop) [[A-F Records]], 2003. *''Fueling the Flames of Revolution Vol. 3'', (One Dead Cop) [[A-F Records]], 2003. *''Against Police Injustice'',(Operation:MOVE, Super Tuesday[Demo]) [[Non Commercial]], 2003. *''Mass Destruction'', (Muppet N.A.M.B.L.A) BANKSHOT! Records, 2003. *''Riot Ska'', (Drug Song, Nobody Is Free) Beer Records, 2004. *''The Kids Are Gonna Pay (Look Who's Talking Now) with F-Minus, Morning Glory, Bent Outta Shape, Blacknoise Records, 2006. *''Sexy Babies Across the Wasteland'' (Guest Vocals with [[Last False Hope]]) – 2012, [[Sexy Baby Records]]. ===Live=== *2002: ''Straight Outta' Naples'' *2001: ''Live C-Squat 3/31/01'' *2008: ''live at the stage @ Arnhem, Holland'' ===Bootlegs=== *2004: ''Fuck World Trade'' (demo) ===Film=== *2007: [[Loren Cass]] (Gotham Award nomination) ==Seen On== *2012: "Couple More Things While I Have You There Now",[http://chewingontinfoil.bandcamp.com Chewing On Tinfoil], 2013 ==References== {{reflist}} ==Related links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061013011158/http://www.leftovercrack.org/ LeftoverCrack.org] * [http://www.myspace.com/leftovercrackofficial LoC Myspace] * [http://www.myspace.com/starfuckinghipsters Star Fucking Hipsters Myspace] * [http://www.rockshockpop.com/forums/content.php?1618-Punk-Island-2011-Governors-Island-New-York-City STZA Live At Punk Island, 2011] * [http://thoughtcatalog.com/2011/an-interview-with-stza-crack-of-leftover-crack-and-sfh/ Lengthy interview with Stza, 2011] {{Choking Victim}} {{Leftöver Crack}} {{Star Fucking Hipsters}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:American punk rock musicians]] [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American people of Jewish descent]] [[Category:Anarcho-punk musicians]] [[Category:Squatters]]

{{Multiple issues| {{BLP primary sources|date=June 2012}} {{notability|Biographies|date=June 2012}} {{BLP sources|date=June 2012}} }} [[File:Sydir Kizin.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Sydor Kizin]] ''' Sydir Vasylyovych Kizin ''' ({{lang-uk|Сидір Васильович Кізін}}; born November 15, 1975, [[Zhytomyr]]) is a Ukrainian [[lawyer]] and [[politician]], who is the Leader of the Zhytomyr regional organization of the [[All-Ukrainian Union "Svoboda"]]. == Biography == From 1982 to 1991 Kizin studied in school number 23 in Zhytomyr. Kizin participated in the national revival of the late 1980s and early 1990s in the Zhytomyr region, attended meetings of the Taras Shevchenko Society of Ukrainian Language and took part in such events as "Chain of Unity" and the student’s hunger strike in 1990 in Kyiv. In 1992 - 1998 he studied at the Faculty of Law in the [[Ivan Franko National University of Lviv]], obtained the qualification of jurist. Since March 1994 Kizin worked on different positions in the district court. Since 1996 he worked in the Department of Justice. In 1998 - 2002, Kizin worked at the State Commission on Securities and Stock Market as an assistant to the Head of the State Commission on Securities and Stock Market (SCSSM), than as the Deputy Head of the SCSSM Legal Department. Since 2002 he occupied himself with the private law practice. Kizin was admitted to the Bar, receiving the Certificate for the right to advocacy. He also became a member of the Zhytomyr Regional Bar Association. From 2003 to 2007 he was a partner of the Law Firm "Kizin, Chibisov and Partners". Since 2007 and by now Kizin is a partner of the Lawyers Association "Bondarchuk, Kizin and Partners". == Membership in the Ukrainian and international professional associations == Since 2002 Kizin is a member of the Zhytomyr Regional Bar Association. In 2006 he became a member of the European Business Association (EBA). In March 2007 he joined the Ukrainian-American Bar Association (UABA). == Public and political activity == In 2009 Kizin became a co-founder of the Public Organization "Lustration". Since 2009 he is a member of the [[All-Ukrainian Union "Svoboda"]], Deputy Head of the Legal Department. During this period on a cost-free basis he has hold dozens of high-profile trials in defense of political prisoners, opposition journalists and civic activists. Among them - [[Olena Bilozerska]] '',[[:uk:Білозерська Олена Леонідівна|Bilozerska Olena Leonidivna]] Mykola Kokhanivskiy, [[Vitaliy Zaporozhets]] '',[http://www.zhytomyr.svoboda.org.ua/diyalnist/novyny/030318/ Sydor Kizin: "Beating journalists shows fear and weakness of the current power"] [[Andriy Korenivskiy]]'',[http://www.zhytomyr.svoboda.org.ua/diyalnist/novyny/028778/ Sydor Kizin insists on liberation of the fan club "Dinamo" leader Andriy Korenivskiy] Olena Halahuza, [[Roman Orynovskiy]] ''[http://www.zhytomyr.svoboda.org.ua/diyalnist/novyny/028162/ Sydor Kizin defended the rights of the teacher from Chervonoarmiisk] and many others. Since February 2010 he is a Chairman of the Zhytomyr Regional Organization of the All-Ukrainian Union "Svoboda". In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014|2014 parliamentary election]] Kizin was 21st on the election list of his party; since the party came 0,29% short to overcome the 5% threshold to win seats on the nationwide list he was not elected into parliament.[http://utr.tv/eng/news-from-www-ukrinform-ua/327072-poroshenko_bloc_to_have_greatest_number_of_seats_in_parliament_327072.html Poroshenko Bloc to have greatest number of seats in parliament] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141110220835/http://utr.tv/eng/news-from-www-ukrinform-ua/327072-poroshenko_bloc_to_have_greatest_number_of_seats_in_parliament_327072.html |date=2014-11-10 }}, [[Ukrainian Television and Radio]] (8 November 2014)
[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/233404.html People's Front 0.33% ahead of Poroshenko Bloc with all ballots counted in Ukraine elections - CEC], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 November 2014)
[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/233426.html Poroshenko Bloc to get 132 seats in parliament - CEC], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 November 2014){{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2014/10/3/7039669/ Party list All-Ukrainian Union "Freedom"], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (3 October 2014) == Family == In 2008 Sydir Kizin married to Marianna Kizina (born 1984). Together they bring up the son Ustym (born 2008). ==References== {{DEFAULTSORT:Kizin, Sydir}} [[Category:1975 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Zhytomyr]] [[Category:Svoboda (political party) politicians]] [[Category:Ukrainian lawyers]] [[Category:People of the Euromaidan]] [[Category:Ukrainian nationalists]] [[Category:Governors of Zhytomyr Oblast]]

[[Afro-Caribbean music|Afro-Caribbean]] | years_active = {{start date|2006}}-present | label = [[Nacional Records|Nacional]] | associated_acts = | website = {{url|http://www.intermundos.org/systemasolar/}} | current_members = | past_members = | module = | module2 = | module3 = }} '''Systema Solar''' is a [[Barranquilla]], [[Colombia]]-based [[dance music]] collective known for their party-oriented sound, which is influenced by the [[sound system (DJ)|sound system]] [[DJ]] culture of the [[Caribbean]].{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/worldfolkandjazz/8081854/Systema-Solar-Systema-Solar-CD-review.html |title=Systema Solar: Systema Solar, CD review |last=Hudson |first=Mark |date=2010-10-22 |work=The Daily Telegraph |access-date=2018-02-13 |language=en-GB |issn=0307-1235}} Their music combines elements of [[Afro-Caribbean music]], [[champeta]], [[bullerengue]] and [[cumbia]], among other genres.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/11/arts/music/systema-solar-rumbo-a-tierra-review.html |title=Sonic Tomfoolery and Rhythmic Savvy From Systema Solar |last=Pareles |first=Jon |date=2017 |work=The New York Times |access-date=2018-02-13 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/systema-solar-mw0002066264 |title=Systema Solar |last=Nickson |first=Chris |website=AllMusic |access-date=2018-02-13}} ==History== Systema Solar originated in 2006, when DJ Vanessa Gocksch offered to create a band to play at an Art Biennial festival in [[Medellín]], Colombia. Soon afterward, the hastily assembled septet made its debut performance in front of an audience of several thousand people.{{Cite web |url=http://remezcla.com/releases/music/systema-solar-rumbo-a-tierra-album-review/ |title=Systema Solar's 'Rumbo a Tierra' Is a Bold Political Statement from Global Bass's First Wave |last=Bryan |first=Beverly |date=2017-01-17 |website=Remezcla |language=en-US |access-date=2018-02-13}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/latin/7670037/systema-solar-rumbera-rumbo-a-tierra-album-fifa-2017 |title=Systema Solar Talks 'Rumbera' Success & Moving Away From Samples on New Album |last=Leight |first=Elias |date=2017-01-30 |website=Billboard |access-date=2018-02-13}} In 2009, their self-titled album was released, and the following year, it was re-released on Chusma Records. An expanded version of this album was later released by [[Nacional Records]] in March 2016, featuring tracks from a previous album they had released in 2013.{{Cite magazine |title=10 Best Latin Albums of 2016 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/10-best-latin-albums-of-2016-w458207/systema-solar-systema-solar-w458210 |magazine=Rolling Stone}} In 2017, they released the album ''Rumbo a Tierra''. As of 2017, the group had six members.{{Cite news |url=https://www.courier-journal.com/story/entertainment/music/2017/01/09/systema-solar-album-review/96346924/ |title=Systema Solar throws own dance party |last=Puckett |first=Jeffrey Lee |date=2017-01-09 |work=The Courier-Journal |access-date=2018-02-13 |language=en}} ==Critical reception== ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' named the 2016 reissue of ''Systema Solar'' the third best Latin album of 2016, writing, "Vibrant and demanding, the Colombian psychedelic soundsystem champions the causes of immigrants and POC while commanding bystanders to get rowdy on the dance floor." [[NPR]]'s Jessica Diaz-Hurtado wrote that ''Rumbo a Tierra'' "...takes listeners on a colorful and politically urgent journey", describing it as "a protest album that never lets its innovation stand in the way of its forcefulness."{{Cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2017/01/05/508089702/first-listen-systema-solar-rumbo-a-tierra |title=Review: Systema Solar, 'Rumbo A Tierra' |last=Diaz-Hurtado |first=Jessica |date=2017-01-05 |website=NPR |language=en |access-date=2018-02-13}} Ryan Patrick gave the album an 8 out of 10 rating in ''[[Exclaim!]]'', writing that "Systema Solar bring a "party with a message" mentality that melds future and folk sounds with innovative flair."{{Cite web |url=https://exclaim.ca/music/article/systema_solar-rumbo_a_tierra |title=Systema Solar Rumbo a Tierra |last=Patrick |first=Ryan |date=2017-01-13 |website=Exclaim! |language=en |access-date=2018-02-13}} ==Discography== *''Systema Solar'' (Chusma, 2010; re-released on [[Nacional Records|Nacional]], 2016) *''La Revancha Del Burro'' (Sambumbia, 2013) *''Rumbo A Tierra'' (Nacional, 2017) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.intermundos.org/systemasolar/}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Systema Solar}} [[Category:2006 establishments in Colombia]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 2006]] [[Category:Colombian cumbia musical groups]] [[Category:Sextets]] [[Category:Nacional Records artists]] [[Category:Musical collectives]] [[Category:Colombian dance music groups]] [[Category:Colombian hip hop groups]] [[Category:Afro-Caribbean music]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Yvette d'Entremont | birth_name =Yvette Guinevere d'Entremont | image = File:Yvette d'Entremont at the American Atheists 2015 National Convention.png | caption = Yvette d'Entremont speaking at {{nowrap|the [[American Atheists]] 2015 National Convention}} | birth_date = {{Birth based on age as of date|32|2016|02|19}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/lifestyle/a53901/finding-yourself-is-bullshit/|title=Finding Yourself Is Bullsh*t|last=d'Entremont|first=Yvette|work=[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]|date=February 19, 2016|accessdate=June 18, 2016}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Newburyport, Massachusetts]], United States | alma_mater = [[Emmanuel College (Massachusetts)|Emmanuel College]] (Boston, MA), [[Anglia Ruskin University]], (Cambridge, UK) | known_for = Science writing | residence = [[Anaheim, California]], United States | spouse = Derek Ross, March 2018–present | website = {{URL|www.scibabe.com}} {{Listen | filename = Yvette d'Entremont at SkeptiCal 2018.ogg | title = Voice of Yvette d'Entremont | embed = yes }} }}
'''Yvette d'Entremont''', also known as '''SciBabe''',<ref>"SciBabe" is an abbreviation of "Science Babe", an alias she began to employ as opposed to [[Vani Hari]]'s alias "Food Babe", alleging that Hari's claims were not science-based.</ref> is a [[Public speaking|public speaker]], science [[blog]]ger, and former [[Analytical chemistry|analytical chemist]]. She has a background in [[Forensic science|forensics]] and [[toxicology]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = http://www.skeptic.com/eskeptic/15-12-02/|title = Don't Mess With Her Pumpkin Spice Lattes|last = |first = |date = December 2, 2015|journal = eSkeptic|doi = |pmid = |access-date = December 2, 2015|issn = 1556-5696}}</ref> Her blog, ''SciBabe'', is dedicated to "clearing up misinformation about science, food and nutrition."<ref name=":0" /> She also works to debunk falsehoods in [[alternative medicine]], the [[Vaccine controversies|anti-vaccination movement]], and the [[Genetically modified food controversies|anti-GMO]] ([[genetically modified organisms]]) movement.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-08-14/'scibabe'-reveals-how-her-medical-past-led-to-debunking-myths/6698594|title = SciBabe' Yvette d'Entremont reveals how her medical experience led to debunking science myths|last = Schafter|first = Monique|date = August 14, 2015|work = ABC|access-date = December 2, 2015|via = }}</ref>
== Biography == D'Entremont was born in [[Newburyport, Massachusetts]]<ref name="Strong">{{Cite news|url = http://bostinno.streetwise.co/2015/04/11/food-babe-critic-science-babe-on-gluten-free-diet-detox-fad/|title = 10 Questions With Science Babe, the Blogger Who Took Down Food Babe|last = Strong|first = Rebecca|date = April 11, 2015|work = BostInno|access-date = December 2, 2015|via = }}</ref> and raised in [[New Hampshire]]. She currently lives in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]].<ref name="Brown">{{Cite news|url = http://www.latimes.com/local/great-reads/la-me-c1-hip-science-20150416-story.html|title = Edgy Blogger Sensation SciBabe Takes the Lab Coat Off Science|last = Brown|first = Eryn|date = April 16, 2015|work = Los Angeles Times|access-date = December 2, 2015|via = }}</ref> She has bachelor's degrees in theater and chemistry and a master's degree in forensic science.<ref name="Keppler">{{Cite web|url = http://www.kepplerspeakers.com/speakers/?speaker=Yvette+d%27Entremont|title = About Yvette d'Entremont|date = |accessdate = December 2, 2015|website = Keppler Speakers|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref name="Borel">{{Cite news|url=http://www.popsci.com/qa-scibabe|title=Q&A With SciBabe On GMOs, Swearing, And More|last=Borel|first=Brooke|date=June 26, 2015|work=Popular Science|access-date=December 2, 2015|via=}}</ref> She is a graduate of [[Emmanuel College (Massachusetts)|Emmanuel College]],<ref name="Strong" /> where she was recognized with [[Latin honors|cum laude honors]] and distinction in her field.<ref>{{cite web|title=83rd commencement|url=http://library.emmanuel.edu/archive/sites/default/files/CommencementProgramo.pdf|publisher=Emmanuel College|accessdate=14 July 2017|date=2005}}</ref>
When d'Entremont began to suffer what she described as "the worst headache of my life", which lasted for eight months before relief, she tried various remedies and attempted different diets, going [[Veganism|vegan]] or all [[Organic food|organic]]. None of these things helped her, and she eventually got the right diagnosis ([[Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome]]) and the right medical treatments for her condition.<ref name="Borel" /><ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url = http://www.umassmedia.com/art_lifestyle/blogger-scibabe-debunks-pseudoscience/article_d7e5166e-5fef-11e5-9541-ef91131f496e.html|title = Blogger SciBabe Debunks Pseudoscience|last = Arthur|first = Christian|date = September 20, 2015|work = The Mass Media|access-date = December 2, 2015|via = }}</ref><ref name="BFW">{{cite web | url=http://www.bodyforwife.com/how-science-babe-lost-and-kept-off-90-pounds/ | author=Yvette d'Entremont | title=How SciBabe Lost (and kept off) 90 Pounds | work=Body For Wife | date=January 22, 2015 | accessdate=January 23, 2016}}</ref> D'Entremont also suffers from [[celiac disease]], an autoimmune disorder associated with the consumption of [[gluten]].<ref name="BFW" /> She cites these experiences as her motivation for becoming a blogger and debunking diet myths.<ref name="Borel" />
D'Entremont has worked for Global Systems Technologies (a [[DHS]] contractor), Calloway Labs, and Amvac Chemical Corp in analytical chemistry,<ref name="Brown" /> and was an [[adjunct professor]] at [[Emmanuel College (Massachusetts)|Emmanuel College]].<ref name="AMA">{{cite web | url=https://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/32aoau/i_am_yvette_better_known_as_sciencebabe_you_may/cq9hqn6 | title=I am Yvette, better known as ScienceBabe. You may have read my article that went viral on FoodBabe this past week - AMA! | first=Yvette | last=d'Entremont | date=April 12, 2015 | accessdate=June 4, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url = http://scibabe.com/coi//|title = SciBabe Statement of COI|last = d'Entremont|first = Yvette|date = June 10, 2018|work = SciBabe|access-date = June 23, 2018|via = }}</ref>
== Work == [[File:Yvette D'Entremont - The Business of Being a Guru.webm|left|thumb|Speaking at the 2017 American Atheists Convention]] D'Entremont started blogging in 2014.<ref name="Keppler" /> She believes that using "snarky humor" is an important tool for communicating science and has been influenced by the style of [[Penn & Teller|Penn & Teller's]] show, ''[[Penn & Teller: Bullshit!|Bullshit]].''<ref name="Borel" /> She began to get wider recognition in April 2015, when her ''Gawker'' article about [[Vani Hari]], titled ''The 'Food Babe' Blogger is Full of Shit''<ref name="Borel" /> went viral.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=nfh&AN=9X9ADVNEWSMMGLSTRY000132259808&site=ehost-live|title=SciBabe's Quest for Truth|last=Peddie|first=Claire|date=August 24, 2015|work=The Advertiser (Adelaide)|subscription=yes|access-date=December 2, 2015|via=Newspaper Source - EBSCO}}</ref>
D'Entremont chose the name "Science Babe" in reaction to [[Vani Hari]]'s moniker of "Food Babe."<ref name="Borel" /> Since "Science Babe" had previously been claimed by another scientist, [[Deborah Berebichez|Debbie Berebichez]], the name became shortened to "SciBabe."<ref name="Borel" /> In response to criticism concerning the word ''babe'' in her nickname, d'Entremont has said it is about helping science seem "relatable and sexy."<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.smh.com.au/technology/sci-tech/american-scibabe-blogger-seeks-chemical-reaction-during-science-week-20150813-giydiq.html|title = American SciBabe blogger seeks chemical reaction during Science Week|last = Carbone|first = Suzanne|date = August 15, 2015|work = The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date = December 2, 2015|via = }}</ref>
Experienced [[science communication|science communicators]] have stated that writers like d'Entremont play an important role in educating the public with engaging and accessible scientific information.<ref name="Brown" /> [[Pamela Ronald]], a biologist at [[University of California, Davis]], applauded d'Entremont's sense of humor.<ref name="Brown" />
D'Entremont has conducted several "stunt" tests of [[Homeopathy|homeopathic remedies]] in order to demonstrate their ineffectiveness or deceptive advertising and labeling. In one event, she drank six bottles of homeopathic remedies sold as "CVS Constipation Relief" from [[CVS Pharmacy]] chains,<ref name="Mac">{{Cite news|url = http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/CVS-Laxative-Constipation-Relief-Alcohol-342025991.html|title = CVS Changes Policy on Sale of Medicine That Could Get You Drunk|last = Mac|first = Randy|date = November 6, 2015|work = NBC Los Angeles|access-date = December 2, 2015|via = |last2 = Corral|first2 = Amy}}</ref> which had no effect except resulting in her being intoxicated with a [[blood alcohol content]] well above the legal limit to drive, as the product contained only 20% [[ethanol|alcohol]] and water.<ref name="Mac" /> In another demonstration, she created a [[YouTube]] video in which she took 50 "homeopathic sleeping pills" at once, without effect.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.alternet.org/personal-health/modern-science-says-homeopathy-total-bunk-so-why-it-more-popular-ever|title = Modern Science Says Homeopathy Is Total Bunk — So Why Is It More Popular Than Ever?|last = Loki|first = Reynard|date = November 7, 2015|work = Alternet|access-date = December 2, 2015|via = }}</ref>
She is currently working as a contributing writer for [[The Outline (website)|The Outline]] and as a columnist for [[Self (magazine)|''Self'' magazine]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://theoutline.com/post/1951/david-avocado-wolfe-is-the-biggest-asshole-in-the-multiverse|title = David Avocado Wolfe is the Biggest Asshole in the Multiverse|last = d'Entremont|first = Yvette|date = August 7, 2017|work = The Outline|access-date = June 23, 2018|via = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.self.com/package/voices|title = SELF Voices | date = December 7, 2015|work = SELF|access-date = June 23, 2018|via = }}</ref>
D'Entremont also co-hosts with Alice Vaughn the podcast ''Two Girls One Mic: The Porncast'', which features humorous commentary about [[pornography]]. After three episodes, it was listed in the top 20 comedy podcasts on iTunes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twogirlsonemicpodcast.com/about-us/|title=Two Girls One Mic: About|accessdate=September 11, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://discoverpods.com/two-girls-one-mic-porncast-comedy-podcast/|title=Trending on the comedy podcast scene: Two Girls One Mic: The Porncast|last=Hines|first=Morgan|date=September 26, 2018|website=Discover Pods|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181027031524/https://discoverpods.com/two-girls-one-mic-porncast-comedy-podcast/|archive-date=October 26, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=October 26, 2018}}</ref>
